title: THE PRIVATE ISLAND IN PATROKLOS
description:
The Island of Patrokolas is a historically rich 643-acre Greek isle that is close to Athens. This isle has been coveted by investors for years. The north side of the island is passable and flat which is particularly good for cultivation. It has thousands of olive trees, pine trees, and a number of bushy areas. The northern section covers approximately 275 acres of cultivable land. The remaining is being rocky with green-hued marble.

 

 The climate on the island is mild and pleasant throughout the year. Two piers allow the small crafts to berth and this pier service the island. One is situated on the northwest side while the other is situated on the northeast side. Due to the sea currents in this region, beaches are large and sandy with lots of unpolluted water that is rich in fish. The island is approximately 25 minutes from Athens Eleftherios Venizelos International Airport. There you can’t see any factories, cemeteries, swamps, industries, etc situated near the island.

This area is considered the most exploitable and developable area near Athens. The infrastructure is prominent and the availability of hospitals and normal facilities is also at a very convenient distance from the property. Currently, there are only a few buildings on the island. Projects are based on relevant licenses that match the natural environment of the island although the possibilities and options are many. There is further development scope upon investment.

title: Futuristic Homes with farming inside the indoor spaces
description:
An average person’s apartment could contain several small and bigger hydroponic farming devices. Mostly the table-top models or units that could hang on a wall are included in this. It seems to be more than a little novel to have a growing system in your own home. Things had changed a lot across years and fast forward for now. Arranging an indoor vertical farm is not the mainstream concept for now. As more startups and major appliance makers have shown their stunning ideas for the past years, these methodologies are on the way to everyone’s kitchen with splendid ideas.  The idea of having a smart farm in your home is not so novel and the majority of people give great thumbs up.

Your contemplating thoughts on homegrown systems can be made away by knowing about what’s in the pipeline.

You can have splendid ideas even though you are having minimal space with smart farming systems. The hydroponic devices solve these problems because it’s small and could easily fit on a roof, a countertop even that little space above the refrigerator. Most of the hydroponic devices contain an auto-watering system, a combination of LEDs and sensors that detect humidity, nutrients, air, and other factors that support optimal growth for plants.

Some types of equipment have apps that manage the growth process and notifies the user when is the time to refill the water tank and harvest plants.  The tips and recipes available in the app let you monitor multiple hydroponic devices at the same time. The device is usually available online. Such devices are used in the UK, US, Hong Kong, and Canada. It is in Chicago the IL startup aim in making a plug-in and goes indoor vertical farms. It is easy to assemble a garden with a starter pack of 12 plant pods that can be directly inserted into the grow trays.

Plant cubes are another versatile idea that headlines by the end of 2019. Plant cubes can automate the temperature, light, climate, and water levels of indoor vertical farms. This appliance looks similar to a wine cooler and is about the same size. The plant cubes are meant to fit in the cupboards or beneath the countertop. The device is available in Germany, Austria, Belgium, Luxemburg, or the Netherlands.

On the go, appliances like Plantcubes are possible to be in the home kitchen as common as other kitchen appliances like microwaves. It is ok when the price point comes way down for that to become a reality which is the reason we’re watching plant cubes closely in our futuristic homes.

title: Corian solid surface in infinite number of colors
description:
Corian solid surface is primarily used as a countertop surface or benchtop surface which was created by DuPont.  Though it has many other applications several solid surface competitors to Corians have emerged since the expiration of the patent of DuPont’s on solid surfaces. It is made of acrylic polymer and alumina trihydrate a material derived from bauxite ore. Most of the Corian materials are manufactured at a Dupont facility near Buffalo in New York. Cross-sections show consistent colors and particulate patterning evenly distributed throughout the material. Corian is the most popular brand of the solid surface over the last four decades with hundreds of patterns and colors. It makes a lot of commercial as well as residential projects the most elegant and smart ones. Corian solid surface has been and continues to be the irreplaceable material in the market for past decades.

The important characteristic features of Corian solid surface:

·        It is a non-porous material.

·        Resists stains

·        Seamless appearance: since the joints are made invisible with corian’s two-part acrylic adhesive. The pieces are clamped so tightly and when the adhesive dries the area is polished and sanded to create seamless joints. This seamless appearance is the signature characteristic of the material.

·        It can be easily repaired and renewed

·        Ease to buff the cuts and scratches  with a scotch- Brite pad

·        The product is Thermoformable which is flexible when heated.

·        Corian surfaces can be shaped and molded into limitless forms which can be used in limitless forms in commercial and artistic projects

·        The material is heat resistant and can withstand up to 100 °C. but excess heat can damage the product. It is recommended to use trivets when the material is installed in kitchens.

·        There is a chance of scratches which particularly noticeable in darker colors.

·        Corian solid surfaces will not lose their visual appearance or fade for many years perhaps for decades.

title: Oberoi three sixty west - India's tallest building
description:
Architect- kohn pederson Fox

Hieght -. 372 meters , 85 floors

Location: Mumbai

Three Sixty West mixed-use development, Three Sixty West Tower B is located in the Worli district of Mumbai, north of the central business district. The site, lying just 600 meters east of the Arabian Sea, is contextualized around the nearby water. This massive structure is sought to be the biggest structure in india.

As most of the surrounding buildings are low-rise, the tower’s western facing sightlines are maximized to offer views of the sea.


The visual connection to water was an integral consideration to the development of the building, and is brought to life on the site and in the tower through the addition of water features in public spaces, recreation zones, and even private residences. Nowhere is this theme more apparent than the building’s pool. Facing out from the north façade of the 6th floor, the pool is located in a double-height space and provides one of the widest views of the surrounding area. Its location in the building establishes a direct dialogue with the sea; while the pool itself ends well before the floor’s precipice, a shallow sheet of water extends all the way to the edge of the façade and disappears in an infinity edge meeting the sea beyond.


Along with its proximity to the water, the building’s design is informed by the concept of interconnectivity. On the building’s exterior, the curtain wall was inspired by the idea of a woven fabric. Staggered and segmented vertical metal fins are arranged along the exterior. This pattern is manipulated based on the function of the space within to provide varying degrees of transparency. These elements create a woven motif that unifies the whole complex and integrates it into the city’s cultural context.

title: Space architecture
description:
Space Architecture- Future of Architects

in the early years, two Florence-based architecture students in their twenties, decided to undertake the substantial task of designing a new way for the individuals of the globe to inhabit the earth. Driven by the possibilities laid out in science fiction novels and the desire to prescribe design to solve the problems of their era, the duo.Their solution was the creation of an “anti-design” culture as a means to provide commentary on politics, capitalism, and urbanism, by creating ideas in which everyone is given a functional space that frees itself of time, place, and the need for excessive objects.

Fast forward to the year 2020, it is the time where the profession has seen a slow resurgence of young, one-off practices devoted to explorations in typology.. These designs, in their own way, pay homage to the influence of SuperStudio and their importance to modern-day discourse. 

In 1971 Natalini said “if design is merely an inducement to consume, then we must reject design...if architecture and town planning is merely the formalization of present unjust social divisions, then we must reject town planning and its cities until all design activities are aimed towards meeting primary needs. Until then, design must disappear. We can live without architecture.” This belief is perhaps best illustrated in SuperStudio’s avant-garde

title: 3D printing in Construction
description:
Making a comfortable and affordable home is a basic human need, yet millions around the globe lack this basic facility or currently living in dire conditions. 3D printings transform access to housing around the globe.

Several months and tens of thousands of dollars, that is the approximate terms of time and resources that one must commit to building a home. Over the past decade, this process has changed minimally.  The cost of building a home is not a feasible economic outlay for many individuals. This results in over one hundred and fifty million individuals across the globe living in homelessness and one in eight people living in urban slums. On the industrial side, the construction industry faces high accident rates, high costs, declining skilled workers, and low labor efficiency. With the new technology implementation and the rise of 3D printing are discovering ways to lower the time and more importantly the cost of building a home.  Moreover in this process significantly has the methodology to reduce the waste and environmental impact that results from the necessary and seemingly home building industry.

 

While using the traditional building technique, homes are building as piecemeal with a focus on various parts until each is completed and erected as a whole with specialized labor. This tedious process requires a multitude of skilled laborers and a significant amount of time devoted to modifying and shaping each piece throughout the process. Using the advent of 3D printing and contour crafting has developed a layered fabrication process also known as rapid prototyping allows construction to occur by processing concrete layer by layer until the walls of a home are completed follow the windows and roofs through the traditional construction process. This method reduces the cost of home construction to one-fifth of the traditional cost and slashes the work-completion to a single day. Additive manufacturing has directly impacted product development for home construction in two different ways. First Contour Crafting is able to automatically construct a single house or colony of houses with a single computer set up. Traditionally the set-up time for a home varies drastically by project and requires architectural and engineering skills hiking up labor costs. Second, in traditional home development, manual construction of layers results in uneven surfaces that are later required to be smoothed and finished. The purpose of additive manufacturing allows for the immediate creation of perfectly accurate and results in smooth surfaces which reduce raw materials, labor, and time required for each part of a housing structure.

title: Minimalism is not a lack of something.   It's simply the perfect amount of something.           For Enquiries   https://www.cdco.in                     Contact - 9 6 4 5 5 1 4 4 3 3
Modern contemporary architecture srilanka
description:
Woven House, Ragama, Sri Lanka

by KWA Architects

Woven House was intended to be just that. A series of spaces woven into the landscape. Client’s main requirement was for all spaces to have an experience of the garden. The design revolves around an attempt to create living spaces intermingled with garden spaces. Six different gardens are present within the plot. Five at ground level and one at roof top. The living spaces open out to these gardens from varying orientations giving surprise and delight to the residents walking through.

Located in a suburb of Colombo, the land is relatively large in urban Sri Lankan standards (1750 sq.m.) and the brief demanded the most to be made out of it.

The main “texture” and “material” of the design remains the landscape. Plant troughs, gardens, plant beds, turfed areas, red gravel strips and large wines falling down at the front provides the highlights in the material palette at every angle.

Art has also been used to create focal points in the garden and within the house. A large wall mounted steel mural is the focus of the main garden. The arrival lobby has a long acrylic painting of a lotus pond welcoming guests in to the residence.

Photography by Eresh Weerasuriya

title: DOMES Structures
description:
Arclif offers event and dome home design with your specifications in mind. Domes are perfect structures and provide a unique environment for every use. Domes are usually futuristic, beautiful, and synergetic structures. It is the common strongest structure known to man. These are highly portable, quick, and easy to erect with a ratchet and have the strength to withstand hurricane-force winds and heavy snow loads. 

Geodesic domes are the strongest, lightest and efficient means to enclose a space known to man. It is suitable for them to withstand hurricane winds, extreme snow loads, and is the safest structures to withstand an earthquake.

Geodesic domes are versatile structures and are used all over the world for certain purposes such as recreations, conferences, gatherings, meetings, museums, shelters, and homes. Many sizes are available depending on the application it is meant for. The larger domes are used for many purposes such as warehouses, distribution of supplies, and also for food services and kitchens. 

Mid-range domes are usually used for classrooms and medical centers. Moreover, the smaller domes are a safe and weatherproof shelter for displaced families. It can also be seen as connected domes that are glued by tunnels.

The use of event lite fabric is light and ease of setup is perfect for digital projections. Logos and branding can be applied to Event lite. This is the extremely translucent fabric that allows images to be seen both inside and outside the Dome. For the long term, outdoor events Event vinyl fabric is extremely durable and perfect. The entire cover can also be printed. For daytime projection theatres, vinyl fabric is available in Blackout. The usage of opalescent stretch Lite fabric is beautiful for indoor events. Translucent quality fabric is perfect for digital projection so that lighter colors allow images to be seen both inside and outside the dome. Dome home design has started rolling into mainstream America. More and more people are realizing that these dwellings are not only beautiful and stylistically unique and they can also be recycled and renewable materials:

  • The frames are usually made of steel.

  • The outside is plastic skin.

  • Wood is usually the foundation material.

It is easy to purchase wooden dome kits and even do it yourself or we can design a wooden home according to your instructions. The dome home can be a permanent residence or it can be used as a vacation home. Minimalist designs are better for vacation homes with a wooden setting or in the middle of a clearing. Dome homes come in a variety of sizes and as per the spatial needs, it is more convenient to design the proper Dome.

title: Modern house design Embraced Gardens, Rajagiriya, Sri Lanka  by KWA Architects
description:
Embraced Gardens, Rajagiriya, Sri Lanka

by KWA Architects

The design was inspired by the client’s need to be close to nature, trees, plants, flowers and the landscape. From the outset views and vistas in to the garden and greenery were seen as an important. The concept to embrace the gardens emerged out of this inspiration provided by the client.

Entering the house from the street one wonders through two garden courtyards before arriving at the main door. Passing a vestibule, one arrives at the main living dining space with double height windows overlooking the side garden and a long grove of tall bamboo plants. This garden runs the full length of the land plot acting as the main garden space while providing a breezy corridor within the property.

The dining area opens into another courtyard garden with a red gravel floor and a large trough brimming with local “Thebu” plants. The pantry space is finished with a top of the range pantry with a subtle colour scheme while opening in to the main garden.

The main visual feature of the design is the first floor roof garden which is defined into the built form through a steel grille structure. There are varying visual connections provided in to this garden from the stair way, front bedroom and the study at second floor.

The Wet kitchen has direct access from the garage and visual connection into the courtyard. Four bedrooms, a study and a rooftop garden completes the design.

Photography : Eresh Weerasuriya & Madhushan de Silva

title: Arclif.com presents Home Design Awards 2021.
description:
HDA 2021 -HOME DESIGN AWARDS

Welcome to Home Design Awards 2021.

The first of its kind technology-driven event in India, to honor the best talent in the architecture and design industry. Home Design Awards will showcase the talent and creativity of aspiring designers and architects from our country to the world. The 100-day long innovative design competition will be held from January 20 to April 30. Nominations for the competition can be made from January 20 to April 20 on www.homedesignawards.org. The winners will be announced on May 1.

The winners will be selected by a jury comprising Kanippayyur Krishnan Namboodiripad, Traditional Architect and UNESCO Award Winner; Sabu Cyril National Film Award Winner and Production Designer; Prasad Naik, Fashion Photographer and Vogue Award Winner; Mathew George, Architect and V. A. Shrikumar, Film Director.

General guidelines for HDA 2021 Competition-

  1. A minimum of 4 image uploads is mandatory for the Competition post. ( Two 3D views, Floor plans, Elevation).

  2. The final date for entry will be 20th April 2021. Any entries after the given date will be not be entertained.

  3. The selection of the final winner for the HDA 2021 COMPETITION will be the sole decision of our jury and board panel members.

  4. Home Designers above 18 years are eligible to participate in the competition subject to post verification of user.

  5. Arclif.com and Xpresso Global will not be responsible for any legal disputes arising from the competition post or user behavior. Such account users will be deactivated with immediate effect.

  6. Arclif.com and Xpresso Global reserve the right to amend changes in prizes offered through competition from time to time.

  7. Arclif.com and Xpresso Global contents fall under the “fair use” provisions of the Copyright Law. Any redistribution or violations of copyright found will be referred to Judiciary.

Frequently Asked Questions-

1. Is there any participation/registration fee?

A- No. Registration and participation are absolutely free. 

2. How many designs a participant can upload?

A- there is no such limit. Participants can upload any number of designs.

3. How to register?

A-Go to www.homedesignaward.org. Click on the register button and fill-up the form.

4. How to upload designs?

A-Login and click on the competition button on arclif.com. fill the required information and upload your designs (Min 4 images mandatory) and associated drawings in image format.

5. Categories included in Competiton post?

A-Urban design, Monsoon design, Eco-friendly design & Futuristic design.

6. Last date for registration and nomination in Competition?

A- 20th March 2021.

title: Advanced Technologies for the Great leap in Architecture industry
description:
Role of technology in architecture

Technology has now become an unavoidable factor in Architectural firms. Since technology paves the way for the advanced architectural experience. Beginning with Arclif.com, we have technology with all its colors that enhance the way we design buildings. The craft behind Arclif.com will never stop evolving since we are looking for a massive change in the architecture industry for the coming years. 

 

Virtual Reality

Virtual reality puts you in a state of immense change in architectural works and puts you in an alternate scenario that makes everything easier. It has now become an important methodology for designers and architects to display everything as simple as displaying video games or interactive short films. At every stage of the building process beginning from initial design concept to final finishing touches, virtual reality lends you to a powerful architectural experience.

With just the press of a button, everything regarding the process of building is comprehensible. Considering every project member to a client, everyone can explore the building in question and take a closer look at the floor, ceilings, building designs to a closer vision. This gives plenty of room for discussions and requests for changes or suggests needed alterations before the product starts. Virtual reality not only makes the project sparking interest in it more than a classic 2D image cloud.

Moreover, Virtual reality can give you a competitive edge that allows real-time changes and reap the rewards of an impressed client.

 

The Internet of Things

 

Internet of things allows connecting the traditionally dumb things to the internet. House owners normally have some technology connected to the IoT. Examples of IoT range from smart thermostats, video doorbells to personal assistants like Alexa which are already common in many homes. And now IoT has a variety of trends in the construction ecosystem. Here are the few steps commonly used.

 

Building Information Modeling attached with sensors

Building plans are well streamlined and create an intelligent 3D model of a building using BIM. This allows all plans to update simultaneously so nobody in the process is left out. The usage of sensors in the building is to measure things such as energy usage, foot traffic, temperature trends, and more. These data collected by sensors can be studied and improve future buildings.

 

Making the world a greener place

Buildings are the places where CO2 emissions are commonly seen. The percentage of CO2 emissions outstrips both the transportation and industrial sectors of the society. So finding ways to make our buildings greener is a must. Designing a building with IoT in mind can help us in a variety of ways by reducing wastes by not needing humans to turn off machines and HVAC systems, which is having more impact on energy consumption. And with the IoT, we can monitor our buildings more closely than before.

 

Transforming Pre-fabrication

With the invention of RFID technology that gains more popularity, we are going to see prefabrication becomes more popular again. It is possible to prepare for a prefab revolution beyond consumer housing. This will be beneficial to design and this will undoubtedly reduce construction waste.

 

3D Printing

 

 To create the physical model to showcase the imaginary structure, architects and designers use 3D printing as an efficient practice. You only need a CAD program and a 3D printer to do 3D printing. In ancient days it is normally modeled by hand, whereas now it is easier to do by saving labor and time. Advanced printing technology is a boon that creates high-quality models and you can customize it with a range of materials and colors. It is simple to do quick fixes with this. If a team or client has any edits after reviewing, it is possible to do quick fixes using programming software and reprint the model.

The above-mentioned technologies are changing the field of architecture from producing immersive visualization to streamlining communication.

 

Advantages of including Technology in Architecture

There are many advantages while using these advanced technologies in architecture to strengthen and support architectural design. As technology develops continually, it allows us to think more creatively and bring those visions from mind to 3D print. Some of the unavoidable advantages are listed below.

 

The decrease in Project cost: It is difficult to change the model after the construction starts. So by using virtual reality or 3D printing it is possible to identify the area that needs change. When you identify the changes, it is more convenient and reduces the cost for everybody involved.

 

Communicate vision easily: Clients and buyers can slip into virtual reality and see building plans unfolding, or touch a 3D print of their new home. This interactive experience helps connect people to the finished product like never before. 

 

 

 Streamline collaboration: Technology advancements such as Building Information Modeling (BIM) helps everybody involved in a project stay on the same page at every step. Engineers, designers, and architects can use a BIM program to ensure their specific plans are in alignment before any cutting or welding takes place.

 

 

Ready for the change in Architecture with advanced technologies?

Many of the foundations of this great profession are not going to change even though technology in architecture plays a major role. Feel free to reach us at arclif.com to explore the new world of architecture.

title: Natural material traditional house kamaroon
description:
Warka Water and Arturo Vittori Create Integrated Village for the Rainforest Community in Cameroon

Under construction in the tropical rainforest of Cameroon, Warka Village is an integrated space for the Pygmy community, an isolated society located in the Mvoumagomi area. Constructed using only natural materials and ancient local construction techniques, the project, created by Warka Water and Italian architect Arturo Vittori, is currently operational, and expected to be completed in 2022.

Situated in Mvoumagomi, about 40 km from Kribi in the south region of Cameroon, the Warka village is destined for the Pygmy community, a gathering of villagers who live in groups of 30 people on average, 100 people at most. Deep in the tropical rainforest, this community is often cut off from nearby towns because of dangers from flooding.

Using material like earth, water, stone, wood, and natural fibers, “the Warka village aspires to transform the landscape of comprehensive human development, utilizing low-cost, sustainable, community-driven, high-impact multi-sector development interventions that are tailored to the village’s specific needs”. An example of how to live with nature, the village encompasses different Warka interventions. It will generate 7 bamboo Warka houses, 2 Warka towers to collect around 40 to 80 liters every day of drinking water from the air, no flushing Warka sanitation systems using composting toilets, a Warka garden to harvest food and a Warka pavilion.

With already 30 individuals living and working on the premises, the village is taking shape, addressing the daily needs of the villagers. Ensuring rural infrastructure, agriculture, health, water, and sanitation, the project, under construction for the past 18 months, seeks to provide essential living services. In fact, protecting the community is protecting the rainforest, according to Arturo Vittori.

Warka Water is a nonprofit focused on innovative and sustainable solutions to some of humanity’s most enduring issues through the fusion of local knowledge and resources, visionary design, and ancient traditions. Founded by Italian architect Arturo Vittorio, this organization aims to bring “potable water, and proper sanitation and hygiene to some of the world’s most isolated communities”.

Using ancient knowhow, Warka Tower, the first pilot project of the organization, allows people to harvest water from the sky. This sustainable approach was first installed in Ethiopia in early 2015. “It is a passive structure, it functions only by natural phenomena such as gravity, condensation & evaporation. It is conceived to be owned and operated autonomously by the villagers. The design is not universal but it depends on the local meteorological conditions, the geomorphological characteristic of the site, and the local culture”.

Shortly after, the non-profit realized that similar issues were unfortunately present in other communities in different geographical areas. Currently active in Cameroon where they are constructing the Warka Village, the team is also undertaking the first steps to bring help to different isolated communities in places such as Haiti, Togo, and Colombia.

title: Pinnacle 221
description:
Attaining the peak of perfection Ar Manish Dikshit and his team at Aum Architects added another feather to their cap - The Pinnacle house. Rolling over 3750 sq. ft, this bedroom duplex is the perfect composition of what dreams are made of. Abiding by his trademark of a modern yet minimalist design approach, Ar. Manish Dikshit yet again worked his irrevocable charm and revolutionized the expanse.

The client wanted to amplify the spaciousness of the four-bedroom duplex apartment that rendered a boundless as well as a distinct appeal, making it aesthetically pleasing. The four-bedroom duplex comprises an entrance lobby, bar, dining area, living room, kitchen, and guest bedroom with a large balcony for the living area & guest bedroom having a marvelous view of the outside. Located on the topmost floors of Kalpataru Pinnacle in Mumbai, the client insisted on curating a space that has a minimum number of barriers, making the house feel limitless.

title: Modern African architecture AMKNA designers
description:
AMKNA's Ode to Africa Shortlisted for the 2018 World Architecture Festival Award

Written by Dima Stouhi

July 21, 2018

AMKNA, the Dubai-based studio, has been shortlisted for the 2018 World Architecture Festival, in recognition of their design proposal of a cultural center in Sedhiou, Senegal. The proposed “Sedhiou Cultural Center” will provide citizens with a rich cultural, social, and educational experience, all while sustaining the surrounding environment and keeping African heritage alive.

The power of a cultural building lies in its ability to morph history, music, food, dance, color, and material into a well-designed, functional space. Senegal’s Sedhiou is one of Africa’s underdeveloped towns but is rich in cultural vibrancy. Regardless of its lively heritage, the town lacks a place of artistic expression and is constantly affected by the economy’s globalization. The proposal’s design seeks to become an icon for the entire country, ensuring sustainability and the use of local materials. The structure will include areas for education, exhibition, performances, bureaus, and restrooms, catering to everyone in the country.

AMKNA’s design tells centuries-old stories of Africa. Sedhiou inhibits approximately 22,000 citizens and has been affected by the Casamance conflict during 1980 – 2005. The Casamance River was crucial for transporting natural resources, such as Kapok, Palm, and Fromager trees, from Sedhiou to neighboring towns, but the ongoing war took its toll on the city’s trade movements, affecting its economy. Even though Senegal is bounded by the Atlantic Ocean, the country suffers from a devastating water crisis, killing millions of people yearly.

Naturally, drought is very apparent on the land as it creates cracks on the ground’s surface. Instead of submitting to these constraints, the architects decided to use the land’s imperfections and derive the structure’s concept from the cracks’ forms and the land’s excessive need for water. The roof of the building is split into inwardly-inclined platforms so that people can benefit from the rainwater harvesting. In addition, the plan was intricately designed in a way that allows natural winds to travel through the building via vents (cracks) on the facades, creating cross-ventilation within the space. The structure will house reading rooms, musical areas, craft workshops, and outdoor activities.

Since it was vital to make use of the existing natural resources, the architects chose to use a clay/mud hybrid for the project’s structure, as it is traditionally used in the construction of housing in Senegal. The architects also chose to use bamboo, wooden beams, traditional plaster, and plenty of vibrant hues of blue, red, green, and gold to keep the traditions of Africa alive.

“The intervention area represents a breeding ground of centuries-old cultures, rich in rituals and experiences coming from father to son, and telling stories about Africa. Cultures here are mixing together in harmony, within an environment full of experiences. Some of those ethnic groups are deeply rooted in history, and, since they never had any archives or written works, they passed those stories only thanks to words coming from the Elders.”

-AMKNA designers

title: Kannan's Residence
description:
KANNAN’S RESIDENCE.

A small parcel of land extending around five cents, situated adjacent to the bank of Edamalayar. The objective was to fulfil the idea of the client to have a house which is “unique” by adding elements of nostalgic-traditional Kerala style of architecture. We worked upon creating spaces inside house for the residents to sit as a family, which include the living room and dining, looking to the green courtyard, where they can perceive the feel of their childhood memories of their home. The courtyard act as the focal point of the house. The design enables view from every common space and the master bedroom to the courtyard. Hence, the courtyard brings in the idea of “nature inside the home “in which we can experience the beauty of sunlight, shadows and the rain making it eco-friendly. There are other spaces like the bedroom with balconies of the upper floor that open to the enthralling picturesque of the flowing river. Even when the house has traditional components like sloping roof, rustic interiors, there are components of contemporary style like a cuboidal façade infused to the design to make it interesting.

title: MADANG.zip
description:
'MADANG.zip' is a tiny house for young couple in Korea.

In Korean, ‘Madang’ means a yard and is a unit for counting an episode of pansori, a traditional Korean song. In addition, ‘Zip(Jip)’ means a house, so <MADANG.zip> means to compress the stories of young couple living in this house.

Korea has a densely populated capital. Young couples prefer areas to live where they can easily commute to work and also prefer apartments that are convenient to live and have privacy. However, Seoul’s housing price is so high that it is difficult to own a house at a young age. Recently, small houses have been chosen as a substitute for apartments. Unlike people in other countries who pursue a minimalist lifestyle, Koreans prefer a spacious house, but they can’t choose one, so they choose a small house. Therefore, small but convenient housing is required to accommodate their way of life.

Theres are 3 factors that are environmentally friendly. First, the courtyard creates a wind way for ventilation that causes air convection. The air heated on the asphalt from outside road rises, and the cold air in the shaded garden under the bedroom descends, circulating the air. Secondly, solar collectors are installed to heat the water used for floor heating. Third, rainwater is also collected to be used for floor heating and household water. These factors can significantly save young couples the cost of maintaining their home.

The various elevation created in response to the slopes forms a step and visually separates each space. For example, a wife in a bedroom does not see her husband in the kitchen. Due to this open design, they can manage their own lives while utilizing a small area openly.

4 masses surround a yard. This form envelops the yard and creates a semi-private space. Since this space forms an intermediate zone between the outside and the inside, it can be used as a living space as well as a garden. The interior floor extends to the outside when the folding door is opened because there is a narrow floor named 'Toetmaru'.

title: Centre for Earth Architecture / Kere Architecture
description:
Centre for Earth Architecture / Kere Architecture

Cultural Center; Congo (Republic of the Congo)

Architects: Kéré Architecture

Photographs: Iwan Baan

Text description provided by the architects. The construction of the Centre for Earth Architecture accomplishes the activities of the AKTC in Mopti after the restoration of the mosque and the construction of a new sewerage system. The construction site has been gained by a backfill at the waterside of an interior lake and so the lakeside has been made accessible for public use. The program itself responds both to the needs of the district management Komoguel as to the visitors of the cultural facilities of the district.

From the crest of the dike the construction site and therefore also the building project are in one sight axis together with the mosque. The building is clearly structured and its building height responds to the existing fabric without compromising the view on the mosque. The visitor centre, according to its program is divided into three different buildings which are connected by two roof surfaces. All the walls and the barrel vaults are constructed of BTC (compressed earth blocks) which are very suitable to the climatic conditions for their natural temperature buffer and therefore guarantee comfortable indoor temperatures. The overhanging roof blocks the insulation on the walls and provides qualitative outdoor spaces. Ventilation openings in the walls and the vaults provide a natural flow of air so that the building conditioning works without mechanic backing. The landscape project includes wide public spaces and a promenade on top of the dike. The project for the new building responds to this initial planning as it keeps adjacent to the dike.

Text provided by Kere Architecture.

title: Culture Center
description:
Walls of tales

Architects: Almena Studio Year: 2018

Location: Sedhiou, Senegal, Africa.

Lead Architect: Abdelrahman Adel & Abdallah Mekkawi

Website: www.almenastudio.com

Instagram: @almena.studio

Status: Unrealized / Conceptual: Institutional (culture center).​​​​​​

Project Statement

Architecture of Senegal has been affected by modernity in the last few years, and the vernacular architecture of Senegal didn't aligned with contemporary people’s needs, so it has been ignored by the local community.

The idea of the design is to create a contemporary iconic architectural structure that is taking into consideration Sedhiou’s vernacular architecture spirit, preserving, and reformulating their local architectural language by giving it contemporary expressions to create an environment that’s suit local community needs and aspirations through dissolving the gap between their legacy and modernity.

The building is constructed upon the local community’s narratives acting like a Griot transferring Sedhiou’s local cultures, pass them on, and preserve them. Consisting of four circular zones. The outdoor spaces between the huts create communal areas to separate the huts from the busy streets cape and also as a place for social interactions functions as an open community center for gathering local community under connected thatched roof mesh designed to be an iconic structure that is respecting Sedhiou’s skyline harmony, and its contemporary curves and lines shine under the west African sun.

The building shows new innovative use of local materials, replacing the concrete walls with locally made compressed earth blocks, coupled with wide overhanging thatched dome that is designed to be capable of collecting domestic water usage in fresh rainfall. The openings in the thatched roof allow passive air circulation to cool the building and light to pass through the space and interactive patterns on the walls. The people of Sedhiou can participate in the construction activities by building their stories with their hands, and next generations also have the opportunity to add their stories on the walls where the walls are built to be timeless. The building will leave a wide social impact, hoping for a revival for their architecture history.

title: COVID 19 AND BUILT ENVIRONMENT
description:
As architecture is closely knitted with the human and human activities, Covid 19 has created a huge impact over the industry over the past one year. Living with the pandemic with proper precautions is the only way to overcome this scenario. In this part architecture could be a part of the solution for Covid 19 to certain extends. Creating new spaces and altering the existing build environment could bring wonders to the current condition.

CHANGING CONDITIONS

Majority of the people are now working remotely. The huge CBDs, skyscrapers and other chunk of concrete structures are now being deserted due to the current pandemic trend. Schools, colleges and other educational institutions are conducting classes online or on shift basis.

At the same time the public places are now used by people tremendously. People now has realized the importance of having a large open space, public park and even a balcony associated with their living place.

FLEXIBLE LEARNING ENVIRONMENT

As educational sector is an inevitable sector going with flow with necessary measurements is the only way out. Some of the changes that could bring to the built environment of educational buildings are:

 

•                Introducing open or semi open classroom concept

•                Provide maximum ventilation inside the buildings

•                Customized furniture with allow social distancing

·    Improving air quality inside the buildings by proper fenestrations

CO-WORKING SPACE- THE NEW NORMAL

Covid 19 has drastically changed the viewpoint of people towards the work environmwnt. People are searching for new environment which provide them a safe and comfortable work space in midst of this pandemic era. Some of the adapteable measures to reshape the working environment are:

·        Create adaptable spaces over permanence.

·        Create fluid spaces over rigid

·        Customization of office furnitures and cubicles

·        Creating more social spaces in both indoor and outdoor area.

·        Need of semi open workspaces.

STRATEGIES

•                Density

Decreasing the densities in an office space in such a way that 2m physical distancing is possible. This could be achieved through arranging furniture, adapting to flexible office layouts.

 

•                Natural Ventilation

Maximum ventilation must be provided in the post covid office spaces. Providing full windows, clerestory windows , louvers etc. must be introduced.

title: Dream interior
description:
The 2400 sq ft Residence Nests in One of the Active Neighbourhoods in Surat, Gujarat, India. The only way to escape from the hustle bustle of the city is to craft a residential interior that gives a sense of comfort, luxury and breaks the chaos of the outside world.

The client brief demanded that the interiors should delight the eye and also soothe the soul. Creating a simple, practical an uncluttered space was our line of action. The palette of Italian marble, veneer and subtle shades of grey was our deliberate choice to deliver elegance and make the space seem large and warm.

title: ARCHITECTURE AND ITS SOCIAL IMPACT- THE TALE OF JAISALMER'S RAJKUMARI RATNAVATI GIRL'S SCHOOL
description:
Diana Kellogg, the New York-based architect bridges the gaps of geography, culture and language to build a school for girls in the mystic deserts of Jaisalmer. The building in made in sandstone and is in a huge eclipse shape. The eclipse is layered one over the another and enhanced with jalis which create spectacular views and shadows. With the material and the shape of the building itself, it is really blending with the natural landscape. Sometimes it feels like a huge alien vessel kept in the middle of the Thar desert. In other words, a feminine approach is also visible in the entire design.

The building cluster consists of three complex- the school building, women's cooperative exhibition cum performance hall and a textile museum. CITTA initiated the project and is located in Kanoi village of Jaisalmer , on 35600 square meters of land. The schools is from kindergarten to class ten for about 400 girls.

The interior curve of the courtyard at the Rajkumari Ratnavati Girls School in Jaisalmer. The courtyard acts as a water-harvesting facility with a cistern in the middle. The rare fruit trees were preserved within the oval with steps around for the girls to play and sit in the shade. The whole structure is covered with solar canopy which makes it more sustainable. The staircase which leads to the terraced solar canopy is covered with jali works.

SOCIAL RELEVANCE

The state Rajasthan has got the state’s worst female literacy rates. This school has an aim to educate girl child and thus to fight against child marriage, infant mortality and other gender stereotypes. Designer herself says that the oval form of the structure reflects the universal symbol of feminine strength. Last but not least, the school uniforms are designed by celebrity costume designer Sabyasachi Mukherjee himself using the Ajrakh print understanding the relevance of the project.

This school is perfect the example of architecture becoming an answer to the social and cultural issues existing in the society without disturbing the natural landscape.

Photo Courtesy : Vinay Panjwani

title: LINEAR ABODE
description:
L I N E A R ❕ABODE


Client : Mr.Bibin Davis

Location:Aranattukara ,Thrissur

Area: 1700 sqft


Client requirement was to design a ecofriendly home within budget .The interesting challenge to design here was the site itself, 

Linear shape was taken as an advantage and it was the root to design process ! The spaces were defined like a linear flow from end to end.The living space connects to dining which is open to a patio with greens and the stair wall will be a higlight for the space . Center portion of the plot is mainly open up for more ventilation and natural lighting! 

The roofing for the first floor centerportion will be done using natural mangalore tile (double layer roofing) to maintain a good temp inside the abode! 


L I N E A R ❕ABODE 

@widearchitects

@francy_varghese

title: Project at Thrissur by @widearchitects
description:
NO_81


Status : Completed


Project type :Residential

Category : Renovation 

Client : Mr.George

Location : Thrissur

Area : 2750sqft


The 40year old house was required to be renovated.Firstly , initiated with space plans and the entire living space opens up into a spacious double-height courtyard with a wooden staircase ascending from the dining space . Atmost care is given in each detail including the pathway over the courtyard to the washarea.


Courtyard is given a breathing terracotta wall on side and similar patterns are followed on ceiling.


Upper living and new bedroom each provided with spacious open balconies.


An open mini- bar module is provided at the rear side balcony covered with rising bamboos.

title: Commercial Landscape Design
description: A commercial Landscape Design Proposal at Ambalawayal, Wayanadu. The Campus is consisting of a Shopping Complex, A star Hotel and a Convention Center. The client wanted to develop the landscape of the campus in a pure tropical style but could entertain all of its stakeholders. A green core was designed on the steep contours of the site which has an artificial water fall, a deck for interaction with water, a designated selfie point, a swimming pool and play areas for children. and at the endpoint an open air theater and a children's play area was provided as a responsibility to the public.

title: HOUSE OF  EARTHY HUES BY URBAN IVY
description:
Introduction

House of earthy hues is designed over two paradoxical ideas: A tropical face which blends in with the lush green paddy field on the rear side and the second one standing out with a modern façade complementing the su-urban context of Aluva. This 2500 sq.ft eco-friendly residence is designed in a tropical site responsive method exploring all the advantages of the adjoining paddy field and is in perfect harmony with nature.

The thought behind

As the name refers, ‘House of Earthy Hues’ – adapts the colour palette from what is around the house. It breaths in the outside inside. The house is an exploration of how spaces can be defined with a framed view of the paddy. The design also emphasizes on an open planning with free-flowing spaces and internal connectivity providing interactive spaces to overcome the limitations of a linear footprint.

Spatial Configuration

The house has been designed with 2 bedrooms, a spacious living, dining area including an internal courtyard and pantry space in the ground floor and 2 other bedrooms including master bedroom with a private courtyard, and a family living space with an extended spacious deck area. The kitchen has been planned facing the open paddy field, where ample airflow and natural light is guaranteed, considering kitchen as the most used space in the house. The connections to the outside are constant, in the form of small and large openings, semi-open decks and sheltered balconies.

The massing of the house has been deliberately planned differentiating the common and the private areas. Ceiling volumes and textures were used to create zones in the whole structure. An attempt in breaking the closeness vertically was successful as the spaces feel connected from all levels. The internal connection is increased by connecting floors through all the open areas which is spread around the plan creating the feeling of whole house as one.  Although the site had its own linear footprint and limitations, the movement pattern of the house starts and ends with open spaces in all directions.

The material palette

Utilizing the vast field in the rear side was one of the major decisions while designing this house. The major challenge was to bring the green paddy fields to inside while providing privacy for all the bedrooms. Also, bringing in maximum daylight and wind from the open fields was another strategy. This was sorted by providing large openings towards the paddy field along with a large balcony with automatic rolling perforated shutters. In the day time ample wind and light is entered through all openings, while at night the rolling shutters can be closed and locked providing privacy and safety for the clients, while wind comes in through the perforations. Stack effect is also provided inside the house to the hot air escape making the house cooler even during the summer season.

 

Design Highlights

The major feature of the house being the slanted exposed brick wall, designed to stand out from the context but yet giving the tropical touch to the residence that merges with the background.

The design has also attempted in bringing nature inside, both with the use of contextually detailed skylights and the jaali which is the breezeway that facilitates natural cooling of the interiors, complemented with a distribution of internal gardens and pools this works together to bring in a magical play of light.

 As the name suggests the ‘House of earthy Hues' adapts not only the pallet but the whole essence of Earth, making this house much more than a mere building. Spaces created with almost details and delicacy to take in the desirable weather and making each corner a usable and enjoyable space resulting in a happy family time in the house.

 

The Master brains

Started by a group of young architects and urban planners, Urbane ivy is the result of the long evening conversations on designs and details of by close friends. Out motto is representing togetherness and growth hand in hand in creating aesthetic, functional and green patched living spaces. Driven towards passion towards architecture and being in this journey together, we take inspirations from nature and believes there lies all the answers for our curious questions.

 

Fact file 

Project name: House of Earthy hues

Design firm: Urbane ivy

Area (in sq ft): 2500

Location: Aluva, Ernakulam, Kerala

Principal architects: Vishnu AR, Nancy Mary Ann K,  Nikhil AS, Anand Raveendran

Client: Mr. Rehanesh, Mrs.Neethu

title: GREEN BUILDING MATERIALS
description: Green buildings are the future for a sustainable living. Here are some of the green building materials which could be used in any kind of buildings.

title: CREATIVE ROOFTOPS
description:
Roofs are not just roots these days. Here are some of the innovative rooftop ideas which can be adapted in the new era.

ROOF GARDENS 

Roof gardens are used widely around the globe for several years, especially among the city dwellers who don’t have enough space for an outdoor garden space. The easiest way for roof gardening is using containers and planter boxes on the roof as they are more elegant, flexible and light weight. Many other options like inbuilt gardening and urban farming are also trending these days. Rooftop gardens ensure the maximum usage of unused space, beatify the space, provide privacy and environment friendly. 

ROOFTOP POOLS 

Rooftop pools are made if there is any space constrains in the site or for aesthetic purpose. These pools are built over the roof slab with proper waterproofing and spectacular views. The shape of the pool must be considered before building the rooftop pools. These are commonly used in commercial and hospitality buildings as it’s a sign of luxury and comfort. 

A PLACE FOR INNOVATIVE ACTIVITIES 

Many fun activities could be planned as a part of rooftop designs. In this urbanized world having a private space for leisure activities will be a boon. Rooftops are identified as such a space. 

ROOFTOP PLAYGROUND 

Rooftop playground is an emerging idea and a need of the new era. It promotes usage of unused space on the public buildings. This ensures the livability of a city and the city dwellers. Spatial considerations must be done over the safety aspects. 

Picture Courtesy : Hiroyuki Oki, Studio Bauhaus, Park n Play / JAJA Architects

title: WHY HIRING AN ARCHITECT IS SO IMPORTANT?
description:
Building a house is everyone’s dream. To make it perfect both functionally and aesthetically people will go to experiment to any extend. This is where the role of architect enters. An architect is a professional with proper architecture degree, who will assist you and give you proper guidance to make your dream project to its fullest.  Architects just don’t build four walls and ceiling or just make things looks pretty. Their role starts from the site selection stage. No two projects are same. An architect will study your site, understand the micro climatic, refer building rules and regulation of the locality and design with all these insights which fits the individual client requirement.

So there are some important aspects explaining why you should hire an architect?

 Understanding client’s need and requirement

It’s an architect who can grasp your ideas and express it through his/her design skills. It includes from designing from the floor plans , creating circulation patterns to evaluating the building after its construction.

 Architects can save you money

Architects can design buildings more economically. Firstly, they know the proper usage of space and thus design in an optimized way. Also they prepare plans from site setting out to the interior drawings priorly which saves money, time and any confession with the contactors in the later stages.

Secondly, architects are well verse with the wide varieties of materials in the market. So they can select the appropriate material which suits to particular client budget. Thirdly, they can design energy efficient building which in long run saves a good amount of money.

 Good designs are clever investment

Good  designs sell easily. The resale value of a property will increase if its designed well.

 

Source : Sketches by Liz steel & Divya Dave, Tesla

title: BARRIER FREE BUILT ENVIRONMENT
description:
Disability is a widely misunderstood word in society . People think that only a person with a wheelchair, blind or deaf is disabled. Elderly people, pregnant  ladies, obese children, person with fracture or with a heavy luggage is experiencing a phase of disability. Disability is a phase in everyone’s life. It’s everyone's right  to live with dignity in any phase of life. Here comes the relevance of barrier free architecture/design. It is creating a comfortable, accessible and safer environment for the public despite any disabilities.

UNIVERSAL DESIGN

It's merging the spaces and user groups and creating a space for all. Uniform distribution of facilities. Many public spaces are still a dream to disabled people due  to their height or depth. Building a  ramp along with the steps can solve this issue very easily. Just a ramp or lifts along cannot solve the entire issue. Some of the possible interventions are:

  • Reconsidering the width of stairs and pathways

  • Sensible flooring and cladding materials.

  • Door handles and counter heights

  • Toilets for disabled people.

  • Providing audio visual signs

  • Auditory signals in public roads

  • Curbs and slopes in pavements

title: Earth House / Tomohiro Hata Architect and Associates
description:
FACT FILE

  • Architects: Tomohiro Hata Architect and Associates

  • Area: 239 m²

  • Year: 2018

  • Photographs: Toshiyuki Yano

  • Lead Architect: Tomohiro Hata

Earth House is a minimalist residence located in Osaka, Japan, designed by Tomohiro Hata Architect & Associates. In this architecture, the earth appearing as a free form according to light, wind, surrounding environment and function is stacked and the interior space is arranged as an exchangeable attachment in any layer. There is space for the external environment to be established in all the earth’s layers, and various relationship between inside and outside is spun. The stacked ground layer overlaps as “sky topography” when looking up, and changes the quality of the lower space. The ground of each layer is stacked as the concrete topography that appeared as a form to deliver wind and light as a curve that avoids the airspace expected to grow trees in trees and trees in the garden. To realize this concept, the architects devised a structure system that three-dimensional branch found in natural trees can support the stacked ground. A steel pipe like this folded branch can follow the stacking of the free shape topography. Also, that is also a pipe space, and the attachment which becomes the internal space arranged in the ground can be freely renewed.

Credits : https://leibal.com/architecture/earth-house/

title: LOW COST CONSTRUCTION TECHNOLOGY - FILLER SLABS
description:
The filler slab is based on the principle that for roofs which are simply supported, the upper part of the slab is subjected to compressive forces and the lower part of the slab experience tensile forces. Concrete is very good in withstanding compressive forces and steel bears the load due to tensile forces. Thus the lower tensile region of the slab does not need any concrete except for holding the steel reinforcements together.

Therefore in a conventional RCC slab lot of concrete is wasted and it needs extra reinforcement due to added load of the concrete which can otherwise be replaced by low-cost and light weight filler materials, which will reduce the dead weight as well as the cost of the slab to 25% (as 40% less steel is used and 30% less concrete).

The simplest filler is to use two fifth grade Mangalore tiles, that is what is used in our projects, they do not have any structural value- they are mere ‘fillers’. The different materials that can alternatively be used are waste and cheap like Country tile, Earthen pots, Hollow blocks, Coconut shells, Thermocol, etc. Besides the roof this technique can also be used for the window sun-shades.

MATERIALS USED

  • Bricks

  • Tiles

  • Cellular

  • Concrete

  • Blocks

  • Pots

  • Waste bottles.

Credits : Architecture and development

title: GENERATIVE ARCHITECTURE- THE FUTURE OF DIGITAL ARCHITECTURE
description:
Generative design for architecture is a new method of design that enables you to discover unexpected novel designs and navigate trade-offs between high-performing designs, sketch constraints, and goals rather than form and co-design between human and computer.

Generative design uses a combination of artificial intelligence and cloud computing to create design possibilities which take into account performance criteria and real-world manufacturability requirements, allowing designers to explore thousands of designs in less time than they could deliver a single concept using traditional processes,” Dieter Vermeulen, technical specialist in AEC, generative design & engineering for Autodesk, explains.

title: CONTEMPORARY ISLAMIC ARCHITECTURE
description:
Islamic architecture has been perhaps one of the most culturally significant typologies throughout history. Not only do the buildings themselves serve as centers for community and social services, but their designs reflect Muslim beliefs and morals, and reveal the rich history of nations, especially in the Middle East.

Several adaptions from ancient Islamic architecture are still used in the modern era. Domes, minarets, jali works, char barh gardens, arches, calligraphy Arabic motifs etc. are some of the important elements. These are some of the images of the buildings of new age, inspired from the traditional Islamic architecture with a futuristic approach.

title: Oresund bridge  Denmark, Sweden.
description: The Oresund Bridge is a marvel of modern engineering. It consists of a combined road and rail line that runs for 8 kilometers, at which point it then transitions into an under water tunnel. In total, the bridge tunnel stretches 12 kilometers, connecting Denmark and Sweden. Construction of the Oresund Bridge was an engineering marvel all it's own. It was part road bridge, part rail bridge, part tunnel, part rail line. The number of design constraints and moving parts to the process was absolutely stunning. As for the construction of the bridge supports, there are 4 main towers. These massive towers were poured in sections that were placed using specially built rigs.

title: Stunning architecture at Baku-hyder Aliyev Center By Zaha Hadid
description:
The design of Heydar Aliyev Center establishes a continuous, fluid relationship between its surrounding plaza and the building’s interior. The plaza, as the ground surface; accessible to all as part of Baku’s urban fabric, rises to envelop an equally public interior space and define a sequence of event spaces dedicated to the collective celebration of contemporary and traditional Azeri culture.

the complex structure forms an integral part of the baku city .Elaborate forms, including undulations, bifurcations, folds, and inflections modify this plaza surface into an architectural landscape that performs a multitude of functions: welcoming, embracing, and directing visitors through different levels of the interior. this provides great ambience for the visitors .In this way, the building blurs the conventional differentiation between architectural object and urban landscape, building envelope and urban plaza, figure and ground, interior and exterior.
The Heydar Aliyev Center is a national symbol for Azerbaijan, a catalyst for regeneration and, in the broadest sense, a regional showpiece. Constructing Zaha Hadid Architects’ audacious design for the Center drew on expertise from Turkey, the United Arab Emirates and the Commonwealth of Independent States, as well as further afield. This explains the feel-good factor and can-do mentality, which made it possible. It was a labor of love and one that clearly paid off, given that it was named Design of the Year 2014 by the London Design Museum - a first for an architectural project.
It is in the design of the auditorium that Zaha Hadid Architects’ approach can be seen at its most formalistic, and its swirling free-form geometry in American white oak was one of the practice’s principal challenges to the project team. For specialist Ankara-based contractor, İkoor, who were responsible for the construction of the auditorium, free-form meant anything but a free-for-all. The architects expected the outcome of their design exploration to be replicated to the letter, providing little scope for rationalization and no possibility of “design creep.” The forms of the auditorium, appearing to metamorphose in algorithmic sequence from one bay to the next, could not be reduced to repetitive modules.
At the outset, İkoor were unsure how to proceed, evaluating the alternatives of a five-axle CNC router-milled solid wood shell, 45 mm thick for optimum acoustic performance, and a timber-clad carcass. They also considered CNC router-shaped polystyrene, strengthened with fiberglass and veneered with timber. Concerned about accuracy, unsatisfactory wood grain patterns, expansion and contraction, İkoor rejected these options for a fourth they called “engineered craftsmanship”, that involved working with Rhino software to accurately construct a carcass from horizontal and vertical MDF members.
These members were CNC-formed, so they could be assembled to form a shape, which is a precise offset of the finished surface as modeled by Zaha Hadid Architects. Next, this surface was covered with four layers of accurately dimensioned 10 mm x 10 mm American white oak strips, successively glued, nailed, worked, and adjusted until they precisely matched the geometry modeled by the architect, checked with digitally generated templates. This was the crafted stage of the operation. Each bay of the auditorium comprises three sections, one for the ceiling and two for its flanking walls, assembled from 8 to 15 subcomponents.
Such was the scale of the construction project that, overall, 230 cubic meters of American white oak were used in the auditorium. Melih Gün, co-founder and owner of İkoor says that American white oak was chosen for the principal reasons that it “would perform well in an application where temperature and humidity levels would vary, it is homogeneous in texture with the right color for the desired end result, it has good working properties and, especially important for this project, its has good acoustic performance.”
Ikoor was not only the contractor of this project, but also was responsible for the acoustics and coordination tasks related to the auditorium. The company worked together with Dr. Mehmet Çalışkan from Mezzo Stüdyo Acoustic Consulting, also from Ankara.
For acoustic reasons, the internal surfaces were constructed as a shell within a box. Once this box was constructed, the internal shell was attached to a secondary steel frame, with rubber pad connections to the internal faces of its structure. An intermediary shell of multilayered sound insulation and steel wire suspension cables provide further acoustic isolation. Although this wasn’t a routine operation for the project team, its greatest challenge was the auditorium’s roof acoustics. This challenge was partly inherent in the project’s brief, requiring a space for conferences, which need low reverberance, so speech can be heard clearly, and music, which benefits from more reflection and richer acoustics.
The proposed use of the auditorium for opera and ballet as well as concerts was an additional complication, because each requires a different configuration of orchestra shell and pit. Zaha Hadid Architects’ prescriptive geometry, choice of reflective surface finishes and unwillingness to entertain acoustic enhancements that would transform the appearance of the auditorium according to its use, wound up the ratchet still further. This wasn’t just an acoustic form-finding exercise.
Mezzo Stüdyo, no stranger to headstrong architects’ visions for auditoria or conflicting requirements in clients’ briefs, was unfazed and, like other project team members, accepted Zaha Hadid Architects’ detailed proposals as a given. Mezzo Stüdyo also knew a deus ex machina was to hand: coupled-volume room acoustics. This involves two or more spaces joined by a common acoustically transparent surface, known as a coupling aperture. The core concept relies on unequal time requirements for sound decay in each space. This entails excess energy in one space during the decay process, which is transferred to the other. This can produce a sound decay that is suitable for the desired acoustic qualities within a space.
In the case of the Heydar Aliyev Center, an unused ceiling void adjacent to the proscenium opening provided an opportunity to construct an enclosure with reflecting surfaces to act as the coupling volume. The configuration of flaps opening into this space was optimized through acoustic simulations involving 8,751 plane surfaces derived from Zaha Hadid Architects’ model, using ODEON software. This configuration of multiple apertures provides a better diffusion and flow of surplus energy from the coupled room into the main hall than would be achieved with one large opening.

title: LOW COST HOUSING TECHNIQUES
description:
➡️Low Cost Housing is a new concept which deals with effective budgeting and following of techniques which help in reducing the cost of construction through the use of locally available materials along with improved skills and technology without sacrificing the strength, performance and life of the structure.

▶️There is huge misconception that low cost housing is suitable for only sub standard works and they are constructed by utilizing cheap building materials of low quality.

▶️The fact is that Low cost housing is done by proper management of resources.

▶️Economy is also achieved by postponing finishing works or implementing them in phases.

BUILDING COST

▶️The building construction cost can be divided into two parts namely Building

material cost : 65 to 70 %

Labour cost : 65 to 70 %

➡️Now in low cost housing, building material cost is less because we make use of the locally available materials and also the labour cost can be reduced by properly making the time schedule of our work.

➡️Cost of reduction is achieved by selection of more efficient material or by an improved design.

AREAS WHERE COST CAN BE REDUCED

🚧1) Reduce plinth area by using thinner wall concept.

🚧2) Use locally available material in an innovative form like soil cement blocks in place of burnt brick.

🚧3) Use energy efficiency materials which consumes less energy like concrete block in place of burnt brick.

🚧4) Use environmentally friendly materials which are substitute for conventional building components like use R.C.C. Door and window frames in place of wooden frames.

🚧5) Preplan every component of a house and rationalize the design procedure for reducing the size of the component in the building.

🚧6) By planning each and every component of a house the wastage of materials due to demolition of the unplanned component of the house can be avoided.

🚧7) Each component of the house shall be checked whether if it’s necessary, if it is not necessary, then that component should not be used.

title: FLUID ARCHITECTURE
description:
When it comes to building something visually striking and unique for people to observe, utilizing techniques of form and shape is certainly one way to create a breathtaking structure, and these fluid architectural designs are incorporating sleek lines and soft curves to showcase a beautiful flowing appearance.

While sharp, angular designs with protruding shapes is definitely one way to create a structure that will stand out from the rest, designing a building that features curvaceous lines and fluid shapes is sure to attract those with an affinity for smooth and continuous structures.

From enchantingly fluid architecture designs that spans the interior of a home to beached whale pavilions that resembles the shape of a curvaceous sea creature, these fluid architectural designs will certainly have viewers stunned by its charmingly sleek looks.

Credits : Tana Makmanee

title: Casa de Vidro by Lina Bo Bardi, Biophilia Home
description:
An environment devoid of nature can have a negative effect on health, productivity, and well-being. There is a direct correlation between clever space design and improved well-being and performance. Even simple changes to incorporate nature into our spaces can have a huge impact on how we feel where we work, live, learn, and heal. From workplaces and hospitals to urban living spaces and schools, studies have shown that adding biophilic elements to interiors can reduce stress, blood pressure, and heart rates—while increasing productivity, creativity, and overall well-being.

Situated in the jungle of São Paulo, Casa de Vidro or Glass House was the first built project by Ar. Lina Bo Bardi. Its glass volume stands on thin support columns that allow greenery to grow into the home.

title: Yunyang Riverside Green Corridor
description:
Yunyang County town is located on the bank of Three Gorges Reservoir. As the old county town has been submerged under the reservoir, the new county town began to be built on the present site from 1992. Thanks to the rapid urbanization process, it has a population of more than 200,000 today. A tourist county, Yunyang is home to a famous temple, a 13th-century fortress and a beautiful natural landscape.

With the wish to transform the landscape of the urban waterfront area, the local government planned to build a coherent urban waterfront green corridor and park system upon the existing parks, wastelands and hillside lands, and make rational use of the huge hydro-fluctuation zone. Landscape architects made an overall plan for the 33km urban waterfront area, and designed the 10km section in the centre of the county town as the first step of the whole project.

Yunyang Waterfront Green Corridor will ultimately connect series of green spaces via the 33km slow-traffic system along the riverside. As the first phase of project, the 10km urban section based on the hydro-fluctuation zone, wasteland, former wharves and warehouses, existing parks and plazas, has effectively stitched the city and the Yangtze River, greatly influenced the life style of the citizens, and apparently benefited local tourism economy. Being adaptive to the shifting of reservoir water level, the proposal presents resilient landscapes and offers resilient functions. It is a green infrastructure that is gradually transforming the city and represents a new framework for urban development.

Credits : Landscape institute.

HOUSES • HANOI, VIETNAM
description:
• Architects: ODDO architects

  • Area: 124 m²

  • Year: 2021

  • Photographs: Hoang Le, ODDO Architects

    he concept of a narrow five-storey house is to maximize access of the daylight and natural ventilation, planting greenery and spatial interconnection of all floors so that members of the family could communicate visually between floors. Family traditional ties in Hanoi and Vietnam in general are extremely important, this aspect is reflected in the design of the house. Open living spaces and a glass façade, with the possibility of shielding in order to create privacy, simplify socialization among the family members as well as with the neighbors.

    With the current difficult conditions of the land, the house has only one narrow front facade, which is very close to the opposite neighboring house. The distance of the facades is only one meter in the upper floors. This north street facade is designed as an all-glass facade so that the transmission of natural light into the house was maximized to create an impression of a more breathable larger space. The different ceiling heights also helps to increase the feeling of enlargement of the house as well as the spatial diversity of the small housing. The solution of the vertical arrangement of the house allows the access of the fresh air and natural ventilation, which is very important in the humid warm climate.
