title: INCLUSIVE SPACES; Social Rehabilitation For Socially Excluded
description:
We are all aware of the classification among various organisms, however, humankind Is an ever-classifying species based on various parameters like age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, religion, migration status, socio-economic status, sexual orientation, and gender identity, etc. on varying degrees over time, which have been grounds for social exclusion. This complex and multifaceted process of exclusion involves the lack or denial of resources or rights available to the majority of people in a society, whether in social, cultural, political, or economic spheres.

The thesis is an attempt to tackle the sudden social exclusion that people face due to a particular incident like acid attack, sexual harassment, domestic violence, etc. The project aims to create a model for inclusive spaces, where the space serves as a multi-purpose arena focusing on its activeness and inclusiveness, assessing the present condition of excluded people in the social, economic, physical, and environmental aspects. The main aim of the project is to provide a space for such socially marginalized people to heal, to reinforce themselves with the help of various tools and professionals; and also, to improve the sociability of the space by overcoming the social stigma around excluded and discriminated people.

title: International Perfume Museum and Fragrance Park | Kannauj | India | Munawar Sheriff | Architectural
description:
_Architecture and Fragrance, both have the ability to enhance the human emotions. In a culture dominated by the technologically mediated information, fragrance provides a subtle counterpoint. Smell is one of the five senses which is rarely investigated due to the lack of language for expression. This thesis is aimed to explore the relation between the Fragrance and Architecture, ultimately designing an International perfume museum and Fragrance park, a collaborative space for the perfumers to exhibit their Art of Scent. Designing with non-visual attributes challenges ways of representation. Which the thesis has tried to resolve.

_Primarily the scent-based artworks face a variety of challenges for their exhibition and recognition on the art market. The site at Kannauj- The Perfume capital of India, offered tremendous opportunities to explore more on the topic. The economic profile of Kannauj rely on the Perfume industries and its by products like Agarbatties and other aroma products. The glory of this city is now diminishing, due to lack of awareness among the tourists and public. In an attempt to preserve the same, the project includes a Museum, Research block and a Manufacturing block as the main components. Being the first ever proposed Smell Sensorymuseum in Asia Pacific, the project faced several limitations. Hence the case studies were limited to common sensory museums and Research institutions in agricultural field.

_The project was carried out through multiple stages beginning from the site study and analysis, finally arriving at a design solution. The design was evolved from the concept to stimulate the emotional characteristics of human being by sensing the smell. The exhibition spaces were carefully designed pertaining to the relevant standards obtained from background study and data collection. The design purpose was not just to exhibit the perfumes, but also to intentionally trigger the forgotten memory of people with the amalgamation of the Architecture and Fragrance. Bioclimatic Architecture was integrated into the design in order to make it more fruitful.

title: MOVING URBAN EXPO
description:
The urban centre is running out of space and has less platform to showcase culture, tradition and innovation. Basically, a gathering centre is in popular demand. An amalgamation of an urban centre along with beach appeal will revolutionize and bring in a new set of standards to an urban centre along the coastal lines. India’s exotic coastal zones are one of most attractive tourist destinations with the right amount of urban density.

City apps are mainly function in few hours in a day of a week and rest of the time its a dead space in the land.such structures are consuming a chunk of land and it is need for getting a solution.

Moving urban expo is a floating structure along the shore and can be driven to other destinations as well. The exhibition centre will also be accompanied by a pavilion and various other features which provide public spaces for people to interact and at the same time make it more viable and approachable. This new centre will be a hotspot for culture, innovation, festivals, and culinary novelties.

To benefit from the shorelines rather than exploiting the land any further and to design a structure to be used nationally, along the coastal lines of India. The scope of the project along the periphery of India is in regard to its three side coastal boundary.

moving urban expo with provide Exhibition space to showcase culture, tradition, innovation– as per the need of the hour,Underwater Business meeting platforms and conference rooms ,Suitable waterfront diners,and a Beachfront Urban square, open decks for public gathering.

title: Habitable Bridge, Ahmedabad
description:
“Bridges are metaphors for everything in life, … The bridge is not just about getting back and forth between north and south. The bridge is about connecting our communities.”

- Jim West

Modern city design principles cater to an automobile-centric city in which the pedestrian network and connections are neglected, failing to create pedestrian-friendly spaces. This notion is evident in the waning effort by the Sabarmati Riverfront Development project in Ahmedabad, which aims at stitching together a city divided by a river using a series of vehicular bridges. Such a problem can’t be met with generic solutions; it calls for unique ideas. This project aims at addressing this problem by developing an alternate, efficient and distinct solution for this through the idea of habitable bridges and to create a City Centre for Ahmedabad in terms of cultural, social and commercial activity.

Habitable bridge means a bridge with permanent habitable structures over its span. (The habitable structures can be residential, commercial, public or cultural) The history, principles, feasibility etc. of such structures are explored within the framework of the thesis.

This thesis identifies and explores the challenges and opportunities of such a project to design an architectural solution for bridging communities. The project focuses on extending the urban fabric across the Sabarmati river connecting the pedestrian and vehicular traffic and to force this structure to act as an activity generator rather than just a transit medium. Within the framework of the thesis, it also delves into modular architecture to explore efficient construction, structural and expansion techniques. The project aims at creating a structure that simulates the various experiences of city life across the river to successfully bridge the urban fabric.

Presumably such a project of extreme expense and resources may seem like a farfetched fantasy than a feasible solution. But the recent proposal for such a Habitable Bridge across the Musi river in Hyderabad to cater the commercial needs suggests that India can handle such a concept.

title: ENERGY EFFICIENT HOMES
description:
Before you design a new home or remodel an existing one, consider investing in energy efficiency. You'll save energy and money, and your home will be more comfortable and durable. The planning process is also a good time to look into a renewable energy system that can provide electricity, water heating, or space heating and cooling. You may also want to explore your options for financing an energy-efficient home.

Cost-effective

It’s got a great EnerGuide rating. That means it’s well insulated and airtight, with high-efficiency heating and cooling equipment that helps keep utility bills low. It’s outfitted with low-flow accessories to lower water consumption and water-heating costs. The people living in this home keep inside temperatures reasonable, use electricity wisely and buy ENERGY STAR® certified products and appliances.

Comfortable and healthy

It’s warm in winter, cool in summer and free of drafts. The home has great ventilation and excellent air quality; it’s never too humid or dry. The people living there use a programmable thermostat to manage heating and cooling at night and when they’re away.

Always adding value

This home’s fixtures and upgrades show a commitment to energy efficiency that adds resale value. Newer windows and doors, and high-efficiency lighting and appliances not only save money and energy, they also look great to buyers. And investments in renewable energy like solar panels can pay off for years to come.

Kind to the environment

All the efficient features and elements work together to lower energy consumption, reduce greenhouse gas emissions and shrink the home’s carbon footprint.

title: Luxury house
description:

Credit to HomeAdore

title: Habitat on Mars- Design for Extreme Environment
description:
The thesis is done in regards to design a self-sustaining scientific research base designed for the 1st hundred settlers on an extraterrestrial ground. Mars being the most habitable planet after Earth has to have a different architectural language. The design aims to use in-situ resources for the construction. The project consists of formulating a settlement for the first hundred people on Mars which includes the study of demographics, site selection, the study of material, food, water, sanitation, energy, technology, and climate. The study signifies who are the 1st 100 people to go on Mars and how a permanent settlement will be created in regards to the extreme environment. The study also talks about architectural spaces for the Martians for their psychological well-being and how the settlement is a self-sustaining settlement.

The thesis seeks to design a gateway to the other side of dystopia. The connection to the realms of a new planet and beyond.

Methodology of research was followed by unstructured interviews of professionals working in Blue Origin, Space X, NASA, and other space agencies, which immensely contributed to the thesis. The draft was also presented to a team of NASA scientists.

title: Interpretation of Library as a Third Space, Marine drive, Ernakulam, Kerala
description:
This project was aimed to build a public library that re-imagines library as a third space in the digital era and acts as a social heart within an urban neighborhood. The project is a third space for dialogue, creative interactions, learning thinking and act as a knowledge and cultural hub.

Located on the Marine drive of the fast-growing South Indian city of Kochi, Ernakulam. It is originally a site planned for the Municipal Corporation headquarters. Therefore, the design also incorporates the functions of the Corporation building sharing the meeting places with the library.


The central atrium of the plaza has vegetation and seating areas for the public. This atrium connects the people with all the above levels of offices, library and restaurant. The plaza level acts as the main third space with an amphitheater overlooking the sea on the western end and commercial shops lining the northern end.

The term 'Third Place' was coined by the sociologist Ray Oldenburg in his book the 'The Great Good Place' (1989). The first place being home, second work, third place is where people meet to unwind discuss and talk about things.

title: Celebrating Tea
description:
Introduction

Tea has been an integral part of global culture for centuries. This beverage is widely consumed throughout different cultures on different occasions. The practice of tea consumption and production is notably significant in Bangladesh as well.

Genesis

The project takes significance of the three aspects (knowledge, culture and heritage) and unify them to celebrate the facilitation by redeveloping the research facility to serve the purpose of these aspects.  

Site

The existing institute is located 66.25 km from Sylhet town and almost 3.8 km from Sreemangal. The maximum elevation of this 49acre site can be seen from the outside, which is 194 feet high and the lowest elevation is 119 feet.

Design process

The whole facility will be redesigned to accommodate better functionality and signify the concept of tea celebration by renovating the existing facilities and combining new elements to let the users adhere to the spirit of tourism and the research process. It will consists of a plaza, a tea museum, an amphitheater, a greenhouse, tea stalls, accessible tea cultivation zones and the renovated research institution. Tea cultivation zones will be divided into three main zones according to their ability to cultivate certain types of teas. The project aims to create a dialogue amongst the researchers, tea-workers and general people through the connectivity of the spaces in the facility.

title: HYBRID HERITAGE CENTRE, WILLINGTON ISLAND, KOCHI, KERALA.
description:
The city of Cochin, well known for its rich heritage and pluralistic culture, has been influenced by various cultures, leaving their impressions in the different fields. Kochi has a diverse, multicultural, heritage which consist of different unique communities. The relies of their presence are seen even today in the form of art, architecture, and other cultural characters. But in this rich heritage place there is not even a single platform to exhibit these culture and heritage of cochin city.

This thesis aims to develop a hybrid heritage Centre with multi heritage resource for the city, and a micro ecosystem for the tourists. Incorporating different functions within a framework, will helps to exhibit the rich heritage in a single frame. This will be a combination of Museum - exhibition spaces which displays the heritage of cochin city. Learning and Performing art Centre focused on creating space for local art forms which attracts people memorize and recollect the heritage value of the city. Culinary Centre with experience zones, focused on the heritage of cochin. Restaurant are conceived in a contemporary interpretation of architectural styles found in and around cochin, tied together through a vibrant urban realm.

title: NASCENCE – PREPEND HUMANITY : Trauma recovery rammed earth center for souls/victims
description:
In this country, we are indeed progressing in various sectors like technology, armed forces, etc. while on the other hand; the number of victims irrespective of gender is undoubtedly increasing. The number of rising violence against women is unquestionably more. Noted that, a significant number of sexual violence and acid attack victims are male. Such cases have given rise to Post-traumatic stress disorder syndrome or personality disorder. A person who became a victim of such an accident loses the strength to believe again, and the terror can imprison the person for their lifetime. Society already starts seeing them without any grace of acceptance and compels them to think helpless and lonely.

                    Therefore, a gender-neutral center for the victims can provide some reasonable solutions to this issue. Such space requires extreme planning and care that will create an atmosphere where the victims from different gender can understand each other's pain rather than being questioned. A place where their stories will be heard and not rejected. The goal is to sustain different lives intertwining together in a sustainable space that promotes interaction and development of skills for activities like handicraft, ceramic, kneading, etc. These activities and participation throughout the day boost their self-confidence.

title: Tesla Park: Tesla headquarters and Curated experience center, Bengaluru
description:
The future of planet earth is predicted based on scientific, astrological and technological advancements, as well as the changing circumstances of all living aspects of the planet- both on a realistic, alarming manner, as well as some utopian interpretation. The project is to create a set of contrasting architectural programmes - a headquarter - business entity as a part of Tesla’s expansion to India, and a curated experience center that act as a dynamic public realm paving directions to our desired future.

The entity’s exponential growth and the ever changing landscape of work culture as well as the growing population, could convert the work process to be either a flexible, co-working or co-living space, completely dictated by the mode of work, creating a multi-dimensional work-learning zone. The experience center is curated based on a transition from past to the future, giving emphasis to spaces in relation to an optimistic future and associated practices. The office campus and public realm – them interlink is the key factor of the design. The areas to address in the design shall be the principles of the company – energy efficiency, sustainability, futuristic design and user-oriented elements.

title: Reviving Lost Lands: Story of Land Degradation
description:
Reviving Lost Lands: Story of land degradation

Reviving lost lands is an attempt to look into the severe issue of land degradation across the globe. The project identifies 'Banni grasslands' as its pilot for land regeneration. The Banni Grassland has a complex ecological history. The introduced alien tree Prosopis Julifora is quickly taking over large tracts of open grasslands of Banni with not just ecological but also social ramifications. Pushed towards a sedentary lifestyle, pastoralists of the region are taking up agriculture to make their ends meet.

The project acts in two entities, one centralized and other decentralized. The centralized part acts as the center to educate and train people to work in the field of regeneration and make a livelihood out of it. Regeneration of land is a water dependent process and the regions with high percentage of land degradation face acute resource shortage (water, electricity, food, etc.) accelerated due to human activities, thus it becomes very important to harvest these energies and reuse the waste in whatever form possible. The centralized center works on this principle on minimizing energy dependency. The decentralized systems are the ones which are deployed the entire region, which help in harvesting the energy required for land regeneration which include water harvesting units, greenhouses etc.

title: AN INNOVATIVE INDIAN IKEA
description: The motivation behind the project was to design a space that is people and planet positive. The modular building system leads to an urban scenario that addresses global warming, food production, energy efficiency and circular economy within the design, so that end product of one process is a starting product of another process. The building is made highly energy efficient with its facade that staisfies more than half of the building's energy demand.

title: TOURISM HUB @ LAKSHADWEEP   l  a water based tourism  development
description:
Lakshadweep is a union territory of India which is located in south western part of Arabian sea known for its undiscovered beauty on corals, lagoons, coconut land and so on. Lakshadweep consist of 36 islands of its only 10 are inhabited and left 26 are uninhabited, they are treated as an islands for tourism development. Central government have put forward proposals on resorts in each islands including tourism like Maldives to develop tourism of Lakshadweep by considering limitations on availability of bed capacity for tourists.

But all these proposals are not feasible by the way they approached. These proposals will affect the marine life by disturbing their breeding locations and their habitats. Not only, the construction approach will disturb the coral frame structure of islands. Already the corals of Lakshadweep are dying due to global warming. So the corals are not able to perform their function as natural wave barrier. All these leads to erosion of soft beds of lagoons. As a result the island which have only altitude 2 m height will slowly disappear due to coastal erosion.

So I choose a Floatation approach to develop tourism infrastructure without disturbing the islands. Already islands have limitations such as electricity, water availability, transportation, etc. Most of the limitations can be solved through floatation technology. By Floatation method we can transfer a structure from one place to another on our demands. So the Floatation method is environmentally feasible comparing the existing government proposals. I had included coral restoration technology by which we can restore the dead corals. Through this we can prevent the island from coastal erosion to a limit.

For my case studies, I had selected 3 type of resorts (Maldivian resort, Floating resort, Normal resort) and floating structures. From my studies I am aware that Floating approach is more sufficient in which region lacks land availability. So here I am concluding that floatation approach is more sufficient and environment friendly. By this technology we can protect the future marine ecosystem, islands, economy, etc. Floatation approach also helps to minimize the surface temperature created due to global warming.

title: Performative and Productive Urban Agriculture
description:
With the ever-increasing population the need of food has also increased. While the urban areas go on engulfing its peripheral agricultural regions, the compensation of the utilized productive land is never thought. This phenomenon has further led to increasing gaps between consumer and food production, thereby increasing food miles.

There are so many public urban spaces in cities and urban infrastructure which are not been used optimally, due this reason of need of application of urban agriculture in cities and existing Urban infrastructure, this thesis project tries to explore how urban agriculture can be incorporated in Elevated water reservoirs (ESR’s) located in cities.  ESR’s are required in cities at various neighbourhood level for maintaining constant water pressure, currently they are used only of performance i.e., of Supply of water but these thesis project tries to go beyond just functional need and make it a PERFORMATIVE AND PRODUCTIVE example of URBAN AGRICULTURE.

These future water towers could not only act as food producing areas but also generate bond between food grow and the user in their neighbourhood urban spaces. This project hopes to generate a more humane food production systems in cities and reduce food miles.

title: MAKAAN - Affordable rentals for migrant Naka workers in Pune.
description:
The story of my Thesis started right when I was a child, fortunately I used to visit with my father different ‘chowks’ of the city to hire labour for the day. These main spots of the city were known as ‘Nakas’ in labour terms. What is a Naka? It’s a temporary phenomenon of about 2-3 hours in early morning during which about 500-800 labours from various corners of the city visit a particular Naka, get hired and the space is again given back to the city.

The Nation noticed existence, condition and scale of workers during pandemic when almost every worker was on street just to find home or a roof above, of which some couldn’t even reach. Majority of community lives in slums of the city, so does rehabilitaion consider the work - live nature?

This thesis tries to provide human centric, temporary, affordable rental solution for the migrant worker community through inclusive densification by accommodating the labourers right at their work place so that they have improved living conditions, easy work commute, take advantage of city infrastructure, have increased tenure security and feel as CITIZENS of the developing nation.

title: Sense Enhancement Centre for Visually Impaired People
description: The proposal acts as a Catalyst to develop vision of sighted and visually impaired people by connecting space to individual’s consciousness by creating a relationship between User – Space -  Movement. This design can help visually impaired people as well as sighted people to enhance their senses with the help of architecture as a basic tool by exploring different techniques used by visually impaired people to perceive the surroundings. By targeting the senses through different ways, architecture can unleash its potential to really help those who experience it in real time. As an architect, we can build an environment which will touch occupants positively through deep understanding of sensory design.

title: WEAVING THE UNWOVEN ( Recycling and Upcycling of Textile waste in Pune city)
description:
A B S T R A C T

The thesis started on a social concern and personal curiosity to understand the waste generation and its disposal trends in and around Pune city.

The journey started with closely observing and analysing this segment in various cultural, social and economical factors and based on it the topic is channelized into recycling and upcycling of textile waste.

The aim is to attain a sustainable module to revolutionize the current Clothing waste disposal trends , which becomes an essential urban insert in city’s infrastructure, it urgers to have circular economy by cutting down textile waste and generate employment for women’s in this sector. It  aim’s to connect the society and community in built environment through the language of  Design

The module created to tackle the city’s textile waste is an necessary  insert to overcome the waste generated and will act as catalyst in Urban Scenario.

The impact of this insert is to merge the link between the source of waste generation and its treatment it will help to know the concern to the society at larger level.

The engagement of the community increases the source of employment and instigate the lost the art of the Handloom weaving .

The change is about to start and work towards the change an architectural built connects the society to bring the change all together.

title: Literature Museum _ Reminiscence on Vaikom Muhammed Basheer
description:
During this period memorial museums are places of transitions. The populations which they serve are increasingly diverse. Not only are they able to collect and display the physical remnants of the past, preserving it for posterity, but they can also tell the story of the past, imparting knowledge and understanding.

 

When we think of museums dedicated to writers and literature, many of us conjure up old-fashioned, dusty homes in which an author once lived, where today he or she is celebrated as a cult or literary hero. This traditional model of the literary museum is changing, with new forms of display and programming challenging the fetishist aura of authors as national heroes or models of pure artistic genius. A literary museum is an institution specially about literature considered as cultural heritage.

 

Under such prevailing situation a literature museum as a tribute to the Sultan of Malayalam literature Vaikkom Mohammed Basheer will stand tall. Such space which inspires creativity and generates a more active artistic expression in the town can foster the literary and linguistic development and can serve as an interactive space to reflect on ourselves. It could inspire people with thoughts and legacy of a life devoted to empathy and simplicity.

title: The Future of Nostalgia: Rethinking Post-offices as a Social Network in the 21st Century
description:
Much of the social and cultural history of the world, especially of the last 2 centuries can be linked with the development of the Postal Services. But today, the presence of its absence is being felt due to the obvious reasons of the technological advancements of the 21st Century. The Indian Postal Service is the largest postal service in the world. It boasts a 100% rate in reaching every mile of the country.

Can such a large network and its existing infrastructure be made relevant for today and tomorrow? Can it once again serve the people and in turn save its own legacy?

'The Future of Nostalgia' rethinks the Postal Service and its Network as a solution to some of the larger level issues of India, thus rekindling the interdependency of people and the institution while creating a win-win situation for all the stakeholders.

This project looks at multiple issues and caters to them on the simple principle that 'the solution of one problem becomes the solution of another'. The Project proposes a new-kind of network which is Hybrid in its nature - a composition of 'Physical' as well as 'Digital'. This web of communication and finance now not only remains to these sectors but now grows into the data, goods, transport and knowledge sectors as well. Architecture here takes a step back; first the policies and services are resolved and then to facilitate the infrastructure comes in. This I call the Social Infrastructure. This project proposes social infra­structure at every level, every scale of the Postal Network; thus, creating part to whole and whole to part inter-dependencies between the man, the built and the technology of today's world. The project in itself is not one tangible building, but multiple connections between objects, infrastructure and public buildings. 'Connectivity is Productivity' and this project efficiently tries to make the most out of what is there for the benefit of the people and their economy.

title: Zolaism Cafe in China
description: The architecture of Zolaism Cafe By Blue Architecture Studio has been curated from nature and its emotions. The space demonstrates irrational characteristics in order to highlight the value of emotions. It is not only a container for specific functions, but also a carrier of memories. The sense of experience and spirituality of architecture is the core of the design. In the open small plaza, several rocks with natural form are scattered in between, supporting a large eave. With its back against the north facade of the original cinema building, the architecture of Zolaism is featured with three sides of glass curtain wall enclosures, forming a whole space that integrates the interior and the exterior.

title: Eco-Floating Hotel in Qatar by Hayri Atak Architectural Design Studio
description:
Eco-Floating Hotel in Qatar by Hayri Atak Architectural Design Studio

The 35000 sqm structure spread across ample landscaped spaces at coast of Qatar includes 152 rooms and other amenities is expected to launch by 2025. The hotel will be generating clean energy by gradual rotation resulting efficient harnessing the power of the sea. Its vortex-designed roof will also be able to collect rainwater that can be used to irrigate the green sites of the hotel, while also being able to purify sea and waste water. The hotel will have three different entrances to provide access from several areas of the shore through the 140-degree pier that surrounds it.

title: Minimalist Architecture
description: Minimalist architecture tends to reduce a home's details and emphasize simplicity, openness, and natural lighting. Spaces are free of unnecessary ornamentation such as elaborate molding. This design style originated in the 1960s and has remained popular in residential architecture throughout the decades. Minimalism is a stark alternative to the Victorian and Gothic revival styles that preceded it; its popularity is rooted in practicality, functionality, and appreciation of nature.

title: Three Pavilions / rotative studio
description: The pavilions are small stations, that are accessible from all sides. They are formed and positioned in relation to each other and in relation to the square and its future transformation. The position of the pavilions divides the square into different parts which represent the stages for the construction works. This division enables the use of at least two parts of the square during the long transformation process. Designed as a modular system, the pavilions are prepared in the atelier of the local maker and transported and assembled on-site. After seven years, the pavilions will be relocated to another place in the city that awaits transformation. he square - the 'urban' plan - positions. This work is not only about the design and layout of the pavilions but as much about the plan to revitalize the Place du Marché, to reinterpret what is there. The pavilions serve as an introduction and stimulus to change the residents' perspective on the square – to bring a different perspective and a new identity.

title: COURTYARD AND ITS BENIFITS
description:
What Is the Purpose of a Courtyard?

In modern architectural design, courtyards have several purposes:

  • Invites natural light. Natural light is one of the best ways to make a space feel larger, open, and inviting—and courtyards are bright open areas designed to invite sunlight, which can rejuvenate humans and plants alike. Internal gardens are a common feature in open courtyards—the bright space is a perfect location for sun-loving trees and plants.

  • Encourages air movement. As open-air spaces, courtyards allow breezes to enter the building during hot summers. For this reason, courtyards are especially popular in warmer climates, where breezes help keep the house cool during the summer, but the residents don’t need to worry about snow in the winter. Courtyards also offer a way to invite airflow without the security concerns of leaving windows or doors open.

  • Creates a relaxing space. Whether you’re at home or in an office, being stuck inside for long periods can be stressful. Courtyards offer a solution by creating a beautiful, private outdoor space that you can use to get some fresh air, talk to a neighbor, or even meditate. Courtyards are a prominent feature for many colleges and office buildings, giving workers and students a relaxing space to eat lunch, study, or chat with friends and co-workers on their daily breaks.

title: ATHANGUDI TILES
description:
The manufacturing process is carried out with immense skill and precision. This simple yet dexterous process involves creating the tile from scratch to the point of creating designs and finishing the product. Locally procured sand and clay are sieved/ filtered together and then grinded to form fine powder. Cement is mixed with water and then converted into dough. Glass frames are cleans and placed on a raised structure. A square wooden frame is placed over the glass to form the tile.

Metal frame which is designed according to the motif is placed on the glass to obtain the design. Artisans pour different colors as per the requirement in different compartments to form the desired motif. Sometimes the color is dropped/ poured directly on the glass top and swirled/stirred manually to obtain a freestyle design. Once the patter is filled with color a mixture of dry sand and cement is sprinkled on it. This helps in holding the colors.

A mixture of sand, cement and baby jelly is prepared with bare-hands. Thereafter a layer of mortar is spread on the tile with the help of a spade and the tile is leveled. Extra cement is removed with the help of blade. The frame is eased out from the tile after the cement is partially set. The tile is dried overnight and dipped in a water tank for curing. It is then taken out and the edges are finished

Commonly available tile sizes
Flooring (0.75 inch thick)
8 x 8 inches
10 x 10 inches

Skirting (0.5 inch thick)
8 x 8 inches
10 x 10 inches

Borders (0.75 inch thick)
10 x 5 inches

title: HOW ARCHITECTS INFLUENCED SOCIETY OVER THE YEARS
description:
“Architecture is all about creating a good quality environment, regardless of whether it’s a home, office or a big infrastructure project. The space in which you live deeply influences your quality of life; so it’s important you make sure you inhabit a good space.” ~Roberto Tripi

All through history, Architecture has stood as a representation of society, reflecting the values, victories, and possible destruction of civilizations over time. From the momentous structures to the homes and buildings that make up the texture of a city, able to learn a part around who the individuals were who occupied them long some time recently our time. By considering the built environment of the past, combined with modern-day investigate on brain research and the environment.

The Significance of Architecture:

At its roots, architectural engineering exists to make the physical environment in which individuals live, but architecture is more than fair the built environment, it’s moreover a portion of our culture. It stands as a representation of how we see ourselves, as well as how we see the world.

While the concept of shield could be a reasonably basic thing, the fashion of buildings was initially formed by the climate of a specific area, what materials were promptly accessible, as well as the values of the society building them.

More than a building :

Architecture not as it were influences society on a bigger level but too on a more individual level, it can have a significant affect on its inhabitants. Everything from the format of the space to the fabric wraps up can contribute towards inhabitant wellbeing, disposition, and efficiency. It’s been appeared that individuals who work in well-designed spaces take less wiped out take off, are more centered, and for the most part contribute more to their company.

Sterile, concrete scenes and dull buildings cause higher levels of push. Planning buildings, as well as cities, to combat this, whether it be wonderful, awe-inspiring design, or essentially a careful association to nature, makes a difference people to feel more loose, cheerful and engaged. Well-designed engineering and the association people need to it isn't something that’s effortlessly evaluated. Be that as it may, we all know the feeling of strolling into a space that fair feels right.

Whereas planning for work is certainly pivotal, it’s critical to tap into that passionate association as well, as they both talk to the sense of encountering engineering. It’s not fair an mental understanding, but a association between the client and the space itself in an passionate way.

The Architect’s Role:

Architecture is both art and science, drawing on and intertwined with psychology, sociology, economics, politics and more.

Looking towards long haul of architectural engineering and its affect on society, we expect innovation to proceed to have a expansive affect but accept that it’s basic that we proceed to get it the human connections to the built environment.

For case, how do we address the developing separation between financially different communities inside cities? Or how do we utilize modern innovations to quickly react to normal calamities or displaced person needs? How do we combat the ceaseless increment of the world’s populace, and make beyond any doubt that our cities hold our inalienable want to have a association to the characteristic environment?

There are incalculable ways that designers can proceed to evolve the occupation and react to the changing needs of our society. We fair ought to step up to the challenge, accepting we’re able of it.

title: The Eschif in Perigueux
description: The Eschif in Perigueux, France was a lookout for a toll bridge. It's an oak timber frame building with wattle & daub infill built-in 1347. title: POST- MODERNISM - A ZAHA HADID CASE STUDY
description:
"I have always appreciated those who dare to experiment with materials and proportions."- Zaha Hadid

Striking structures and inventive plans are the trademarks of the modern Architects. Innovators accepted nothing was as well brave: their courageous glass towers, seem alter society; their planned cities guaranteed Ideal world. These dreams did not continuously come genuine, but today's 'star' architects still accept buildings can have a significant impact on individuals. Architect Frank Gehry, after all, spared the coming up short economy of Bilbao, giving the Spanish city a modern driving force as a social industry middle with his radical plan for the Guggenheim Exhibition hall there.Architect like Zaha Hadid played the major part in improvement of Post-modernism.

Progresses in innovation, especially computerisation, have upgraded the imaginative conceivable outcomes of engineering plan, in spite of the fact that designers must still consider the essentials of work and relationship to location. Other challenges for the twenty-first-century planner are vitality sparing, building time and financial contemplations. Planners work inside the worldwide economy. Exceptionally effective ones build up their claim firms, have workplaces in different cities around the world and utilize expansive staffs. The leading planners adjust creativity, innovation and usefulness with social contemplations to form distinctive and fabulous signature buildings. Since globalization tends to make a ‘sameness’, there's too an expanded require for obvious originality.

Why is Zaha Hadid's approach unique -

Hadid's approach to building plan is exceedingly inventive and unique. Her structures challenge past concepts of what a building ought to be. The liquid vitality of her buildings is sculptural in approach. Conceptual System — inventive in approach to a building's work and the stream of individuals towards and inside it.

Zaha Hadid's radical fashion includes a unused approach to design, with different viewpoint focuses, smooth surfaces where dividers appear to soften, ceilings show up to compress, twist and extend, and floors bend upwards. Her plans appear to deny the concept of strength customarily related with engineering. Her shapes show up to be in a steady state of alter, morphing and floating as in case in a science fiction motion picture, drawing the passerby into her individual daydream. Her structures reflect a interesting appreciation of structural frame, the accentuation on shadow and uncertainty a reference to her social roots, whereas the smoothness could be a response against the tightening influences, as she sees them, of cutting edge urban scenes.

In spite of the fact that Architect requires person motivation, it too includes a parcel of individuals. Hadid herself does not like utilizing computers, leaning toward to draw her ideas, working out theoretical spatial connections on paper. She is especially inquisitive about how the relationship of floor to divider and ceiling can be re-imagined.

Now let's look into some of her masterpiece projects.

London Aquatic Centre,London,UK -

The futuristic, dynamic design for the London Aquatic Centre has an organic, living quality. Its shape evokes a stingray or a crashing wave, suitable symbols for the intended function of the building. The curvilinear shapes slide gently along the foreshore as if about to slip back into the water. The overhanging curve seems to gather onlookers together protectively below it, drawing them towards the building, stimulating their involvement.

The ladder-like structures inside the glass façade inspire spectators to visually climb to the peak of the building. For those who cast their eyes downwards to the pavement, the repetitive horizontal rungs draw the eye upward, intimating a rise in expectations and ideals. Each curving rib of the roof sets up a forward surging motion in a rising crescendo, symbolising an ongoing energy within the building. The building is streamlined, flowing and highly individualistic, a fitting design for a prestigious event and for highlighting Britain's creative energy. It also highlights the exciting possibilities for architecture offered by computer-aided design. There is a strength and distinction to the design that reflects Zaha Hadid's own personality.

Opus (2011),Dubai Omniyat Properties -

This staggering building ought to be a stand-out in Commerce Cove, Dubai, a nation as of now known for its energizing, imaginative structural structures. It is to be a mixed-usage property with shopping outlets on the primary three floors, and the best floor advertising a ‘tranquillity zone’ total with pool and a beach. Despite its rectilinear frame it includes a solid sculptural feel. We are reminded of the glass dividers of lace windows of the Innovator Worldwide School, and the way it floats is comparable to Le Corbusier's concept of raising a building on pilotis, but the momentous part in one side of the building and the ‘carved out’ shape in another are unquestionably modern statements.

Not at all like pioneer designers who attempted to create a unmistakable ‘style’ or approach, embracing directing standards such as ‘less is more’, ‘form takes after function’, ‘a house ought to be of a slope not on a hill’, modern planners such as Zahid, Norman Cultivate and Amanda Levete appear to delight in making interesting structural articulations with each extend. To a few degree it is modern technology that is making conceivable such fiercely inventive plans.

Hadid is an persuasive designer with a groundbreaking approach to plan. Numerous of her buildings are raised so as to take off the space underneath free for urban living, permitting her structures to stay liquid and active, invigorating development and dissolving classic boundaries. Hadid's buildings don't take after a set equation; her objectives are to form buildings that are right for the put and the client, and to advance a sense of optimism.

So let's take a moment to admire the complexness and harmony that Zaha Hadid have belended to create a unique spatial experience.

Sreeraj Jagan.

title: DECONSTRUCTIVISM - SPOTLIGHT ON FRANK GEHRY'S STYLE
description:
"I approach each project with a new insecurity, almost like the first project I ever did, and I get the sweats, I go in and start working, I'm not sure where I'm going" - Frank Gehry

Deconstructive and genuinely extraordinary Canadian-American architect Gehry plays with deconstructivism like no-one else. Indeed at the age of 91, the 'starchitect' is appearing no signs of ceasing.

Envision living in a rural neighborhood of Los Angeles within the 1970s. Everything on your road is ''normal'' until a neighbour Architect remodels his house. With folded metal, uncovered joists and studs, and chain-link fencing, this house looks so diverse than the colonial fashion houses around. Your neighbors do not like it; one pledges to have the Architect imprisoned, and another undermines to sue. The Architect in this story is Canadian-born, American Straight to the point Gehry, and the house is his to begin with explanation on deconstructivism which he was not captured but granted for. In 1988, Gehry's house was shown at the Exhibition hall of Present day Craftsmanship (Modern York) as an case of deconstructivist engineering. The taking after year, Gehry won the Pritzker Design Prize.

Deconstructivism is grounded within the philosophical speculations of Jacques Derrida and were applied to design within the 1980s. Deconstructivist Architects dismiss the standards of innovation, such as geometric virtue of frame and form-function relationship. Instep, they disturb the building framework and control the form. Gehry has planned numerous ''wow'' buildings which are associated with deconstructivist engineering. For numerous, he could be a 'starchitect' who twice changed the course of design. But, Gehry not one or the other characterizes himself as a deconstructivist planner nor likes to be named a starchitect. Let's see how this celebrated modeler profoundly tests in deconstructivism.

GEHRY'S ARCHITECTURE PHILOSPHY-

Gehry's deconstructivist design is like jazz music. He makes a dialect of engineering by ad libbing and making ''something'' unmistakable with the components of engineering. But this dialect doesn't conversation around solidarity, agreement, and clarity, like in innovation. In differentiate, Gehry extraordinary to form disharmony and visual confusion. He needs to specific feeling and make a sense of development with his buildings. In this way, Gehry sees design as craftsmanship and questions a building's implies of expression, like in form.

Gehry's Forms -

Gehry's design works at the side design. His shapes are a combination of design. Gehry employments skewed geometry and makes heterogeneous, non-rectilinear, and curvilinear shapes that are mutilated, separated, and persistently distorted. Gehry's shapes have no virtue, redundancy, or a sense of solidness. They have a distinctive sensibility, as his buildings appear to move and continually change. Form doesn't take after work in Gehry's hands, as well. Gehry's shapes break with the presumptions of their capacities. For case, can you tell where the library is at his Guggenheim Bilbao Exhibition hall? How approximately the eatery? There's no clue from exterior, right? Gehry starts working on the shape, and the program and capacities of the building adjust to it afterward.

Gehry & Structure -

Irregular geometry could be a implies of formal aesthetic in Gehry's buildings. But it could be a basic condition as well. Structure is basic for Gehry's engineering where shape and structure ended up one. By structure, not as it were the auxiliary components (such as pillars and columns) but moreover the envelope of a building is meant. Gehry liberates the skin from its part of fair encasing the space and covering the building, and permits it to control the structure. At the Exhibition hall of Pop Culture (once in the past EMP), for illustration, the skin brings out the shake 'n' roll involvement with its undulating bends and intense corners. This ebb and flow oversees the structure, which makes disconnected inward and external geometries.

Frank Gehry was one such pioneer in this field who knows exactly what he does and plays with form and space like his toys. Even though his works have recieved a lot of criticisms over these years , all have agreed in unison the fact that his buildings are a 'marvel' to behold.

Sreeraj Jagan.

title: IN- MIGRANT CONSTRUCTION WORKERS : THE REAL UNSUNG HEROES
description:
'There are more over 40,00,000 in-migrant construction workers in the state of kerala alone.And their pay scale and living condition are well below the standards' - study

🗣️Architects and Civil engineers are not the actual stars in the construction industries.

The major workforce that enebles us to build these skyscrapers within a short periods are the construction labours who are ready to work overtime with low wages.

In-migration with its significant impact on various spheres of life is relatively new experience in the long history of my native state, Kerala ,which was otherwise considered as a region dominating in out-migration Majority of these in-migrant workers in Kerala are employed in the construction sector. The construction work is hard physical labour often under difficult conditions like adverse weather, low pay and poor living conditions with lack of basic amenities and separation from family.

Construction activities are associated with every phase of development of an economy. The construction  work  is  a  perennial  industry  and  a  very  crucial  one,  providing  substantial employment  opportunities  to  unskilled  labourers.  A  high  proportion  of  socially  and economically  weaker  sections  of  the  society  are  engaged  in  the  unorganized  economic activities  in  India  and  Kerala. 

Majority  of  the  in-migrant  workers  are  employed  in  the informal construction sector  in the  Kerala. They  often  work  long  hours  in  poor working conditions, devoid of social security and  legal protection Since in-migrants are  unaware of laws and policies, they are exploited in the construction sector of the State.There is a need to ensure  that  all  migrants  and  their  families  have  access  to  services  and  entitlements  as enshrined in policies and law.

They deserve all the respects and credits for the skills and service that they provide to this nation.

Sreeraj Jagan.

title: THE 'ARCHITECT' IN ARCHITECTURE
description:
“Architecture should speak of its time and place, but yearn for timelessness” - Frank Gehry

The ‘architect’ has apparently misplaced the creation and restrictiveness she/he once possessed—an perception that can be obvious not as it were in India but around the world. Nowadays, the collaborative part of architect instep rests on engineers, clients, different experts, and outside firms which are supressing the voice of the architect.It is imperative that the part of the architect be recognized more unequivocally, particularly within the planning of cities.

The Indian government’s enormous Smart Cities Mission, which points to create maintainable and citizen-friendly cities all over the nation, has done exceptionally small to incorporate structural voices into the discussion. Same goes for our heritage structures that are being supplanted by advanced structures in spite of resistance offered by architects.

As a result, architects are making endeavors and are routinely making stages that can provide a way to superior design.Various worldwide architectural traditions are too making openings of expanded perceivability. Here, major discourses on burning points such as maintainability and the green development, integration of urban arranging and engineering, and the part of architect in arranging the cities, are being investigated.

These conversations about how architecture professionals can better serve society are also included in conversations between architects, governmental bodies, environmentalists, citizens and psychologists.

Women’s support within the field is certainly developing around the world, but especially in India, where they are contributing to architecture and arranging in a bunch of ways and are holding definitive positions.This is a far cry from the gender-biased profession architecture was in India even a decade back. Needless to say, on many forums, it is the women who are initiating changes.

title: HOW WE FEEL ARCHITECTURE
description:
As more of us flock to urban living, city designers are re-thinking buildings’ influence on our moods in an era of “neuro-architecture”.

We now know, for example, that buildings and cities can affect our mood and well-being, and that specialised cells in the hippocampal region of our brains are attuned to the geometry and arrangement of the spaces we inhabit.People generally prefer free flowing or organic lines than strictly articulated lines,it makes them feel more relaxed.

Yet urban architects have often paid scant attention to the potential cognitive effects of their creations on a city’s inhabitants. The imperative to design something unique and individual tends to override considerations of how it might shape the behaviours of those who will live with it. That could be about to change.

Because of psychological studies, we have a much better idea of the kind of urban environments that people like or find stimulating. Some of these studies have attempted to measure subjects’ physiological responses in situ, using wearable devices such as bracelets that monitor skin conductance (a marker of physiological arousal), smartphone apps that ask subjects about their emotional state, and electroencephalogram (EEG) headsets that measure brain activity relating to mental states and mood.

The importance of urban design goes far beyond feel-good aesthetics. A number of studies have shown that growing up in a city doubles the chances of someone developing schizophrenia, and increases the risk for other mental disorders such as depression and chronic anxiety.

The main trigger appears to be the “social stress” – the lack of social bonding and cohesion in neighbourhoods.Urban living can change brain biology in some people, resulting in reduced gray matter in the right dosolateral prefrontal cortex and the perigenual anterior cingulate cortex, two areas where changes have previously been linked to early-life stressful experiences.

It sounds counterintuitive: surely the sheer number of people makes social interaction more likely. While this may be true superficially, the kind of meaningful social interactions that are crucial for mental health do not come easily in cities. Social isolation is now recognised by urban authorities as a major risk factor for many illnesses. Is it possible to design against it, to build in a way that encourages connection?

Visual complexity of natural environments acts as a kind of mental balm.

Sreeraj Jagan.

title: House of Terraces / Architecture Paradigm
description:

Situated on a small hillock, the approach to the site begins with a climb towards the west. A winding road leads to the site which is bounded on the east by this access road and neighboring properties around on the 3 sides. The land starts dipping starkly beyond this eastern road thus affording panoramic views from the site towards the city. 

The other key aspect that informed the design was the site’s overgrown wild vegetation during the initial inspection. It had remained untouched for a few years and the surreal presence of this very dense, dark, and overwhelming wild growth amidst neat houses around greeted us during the first visit. The design for the house rested on five principles of views, vegetation, layering, terraces, and interconnection of inside and outside.

title: LANDSCAPE ARCHITECT : THE CONSERVATIONIST AMONG ARCHITECTS
description:
‘‘Landscape architecture is about the planning, design, management, and nurturing of the built and natural environments. With their unique skill set, landscape architects work to improve human (genrally, all living species) and environmental health in all communities. They plan and design parks, campuses, streetscapes, trails, plazas, residences, and other projects that strengthen communities.’’

Currently, our world is undergoing an environmental crisis, affecting the wellbeing and livelihood of millions of ubiquitously. The unchecked urban sprawl has resulted in the severity of environmental hazards and natural disasters like frequent flooding, air and water pollution, exhaustion of resources and energy, to name a few.

Amidst mindless concretisation of the world post-industrialization, a disconnection between nature and the city began which continues till today. Urbanisation and densification processes have led to a loss of urban green space and biodiversity within cities.

Landscape architects have a holistic approach to design and closely work with allied professions (Architects, Civil engineers, Surveyors, etc) to prepare a proposal. They also collaborate with environmental scientists, ecologists, hydrologists and other professionals to find the best way to conserve or restore natural resources.They then analyse the natural elements of the site, such as the climate, soil, slope of the land, drainage, and vegetation.Landscape architects create detailed plans indicating new topography, vegetation, walkways, and other landscaping details, stormwater drainage.

Landscape architects have widened their perspectives and professional reach to take on more than merely the landscape: increasingly, the city, Communities, Ecology and the environment at large are the purviews of this evolving profession.Because of the sensitivity they carry, the landscape professionals are involved in different scales of work ranging from residential areas, street design, public spaces and parks to urban design and city planning.

Therefore the role of a landscape architecture is very profound in creating meaningful spaces that co-exist with nature in harmonious way which in back provides well-being of living creatures.

Sreeraj Jagan.

title: LAURIE BAKER : GANDHI OF ARCHITECTURE

I think these small variations give tremendous character to a wall made of thousands of bricks, so I never dream of covering such a unique and characterful creation with plaster, which is mainly dull and characterless. I like the contrast of textures of brick, of stone, of concrete, of wood.' - Laurie Baker

Feasible, Natural, and Vernacular Design all synonymous to one of the most prominent pioneers of this fashion, Lawrence Wilfred Baker, a British born architect. Moreover known as the 'Gandhi of architecture', he reminds us that the genuine meaning of architecture lies within the mindful and judicious utilize of constrained assets and guzzling the characteristics that encompass it.

Baker accepted that the building to be planned infers its identity from the clients who utilize it.

His work reflects the same and rouses us to consolidate and construct one of a kind, individual structures among the sea of exceedingly commercialized, look-alike buildings with no personality.

Visualizing the building as a completed energetic state with the clients utilizing it, is the extreme objective of an designer.Baker comparing his calling to that of a Melodic conductor who controls all the melodic disobedient in his symphony and has an generally see of how it sounds together to form the culminate ensemble makes much sense when as an architect, we realize that it is our obligation to facilitate and oversee all the technical aspects of building development to attain the idealize composition for our client.

He focused more on “Common Sense”, whereas planning which emphasizes dodging the abundance and the luxury. The obligation of an designer is to acknowledge a brief that he is able of performing whereas empowering his client provide to give up that which isn't vital. As an designer, we must inquire about and think about our site, its advantages, and its deficiencies, and make the foremost we are able in an fair and effective way. His rationalities of cost-effective, energy-efficient plans utilizing inborn materials were absorbed through the different encounters that instructed him the significance of these viewpoints.

Most individuals relate Laurie Baker with Brick construction but Laurie legitimately focuses out that, it is as it were his most later and known buildings in Kerala that have bricks as its essential building fabric. Baker isn't particular to one single fabric but different innate materials based on its Building area. Baker's style in Uttar Pradesh, Gujarat, and West Bengal all change as per their area but their center reasoning remains the same.

Laurie Baker’s bequest presently lives through his Middle for Environment thinks about found in Kerala. The different Programs and Summer schools organized his lessons and empowered his feasible fashion of Engineering. In an period where Nature itself rebels against the abominations that have won somewhat due to building development strategies, we realize the significance of Laurie Baker’s economical approach for a secure and comfortable future.

Sreeraj Jagan.

title: Boss Design: Adapting to the Demands of Flexible Workspaces
description:
The demands and expectations of the workplace have shifted dramatically over the last two years. The mission statement of the office is being re-drafted and its role and function re-defined. Mark Barrell, Design Director at global furniture manufacturer Boss Design, argues that the advance of hybrid or blended work – and 80 per cent of Boss’ clients have adopted that model – means that offices must become 'destination spaces', or rather a series of different destination spaces.

Crucially, Barrell says, time in the shared workplace is now less a matter of routine and prescribed shifts than purpose. And people will need different types of workspace depending on that purpose.

The office is now primarily a place to connect with company culture, collaborate with teammates and to learn or pass on learning, says Barrell. Head-down, focused desk work will still happen but ranks upon ranks of desks and task chairs is clearly an outdated model of office organization. "The best working environments offer a combination of work, interaction and relaxation," he says.

Reimagining the wingback chair

Barrell argues that a key trend at the moment is a softening of office fixtures and fittings, not a forced or contrived domestication, but a greater emphasis on comfort and more relaxed settings. Boss' new Amelia wingback chair exemplifies that trend.

Boss designer Aaron Clarkson wanted to create an iconic silhouette that could stand the test of time but also a chair that had a visual and actual softness and tactility. With Amelia, Clarkson elegantly re-imagines the traditional wingback as a single, gently curving form and has worked with Boss' master upholsterers to ensure that multiple fabrics work seamlessly with his simple organic lines. In the office environment, Amelia becomes a kind of instant comfortable cocoon, offering visual and acoustic privacy. Amelia can also be configured with one of four different bases and with standard or plush upholstery.

Modular, flexible workspaces

While work pods offer welcome private space, Barrell argues that most fall short as pleasant, productive places to be. Boss’ new Mews modular pod system offers softer and more textured natural materials but also better acoustics, air quality and video conference-friendly lighting. As Barrell says, Teaming, Zooming and similar are now a permanent feature of working life and Boss worked with photographers and videographers when creating the lighting for Mews, ensuring your onscreen presence is as polished as possible.

The Mews pod system has also been designed to create usable working and meeting space between pods, which can also be curtained off for privacy. "We feel like successful workplace planning, now perhaps more than ever, relies on high levels of flexibility, modularity and adaptability," says Barrell.

Credits : Archdaily

title: Wire-cut bricks can decorate your homes
description:
Wire-cut bricks are cured or fired pieces of clay that have been formed into brick shapes with the aid of a wire cutter of some sort. The simplest cutters are little more than wire cording that people press into large mounds of clay to divide it into smaller portions. Wire-cut bricks are an excellent cladding option for architecturally elegant buildings. These cladding bricks come in multiple styles such as regular commercial bricks, dark blend facing bricks, accent white blend facing bricks, weathered facing bricks, and country blend facing bricks.

Use wire cut bricks if you want to have an unplastered wall. The surface and edges of wire-cut brick have a better finishing compared to standard table mold bricks. The advantages of using wirecut bricks are not just saving the cost of plastering or saving the future cost of maintenance of painting, but also has a raw look and avoid using paint.

title: How to Use Different Types of Floors in the Same Environment?
description:
The floor is one of the largest areas of coverage of an environment, and therefore, its choice goes through several criteria related to both aesthetic and visual identity issues, as well as technical issues of resistance and maintenance. It is common to use different floors for areas with different uses and often this transition is not marked by walls or doors. Next, we will bring you tips on how to make this transition harmoniously when there is no physical boundary between the floors.

We are used to using different floors to demarcate areas with different uses: kitchen and dining room, living room and balcony, or even living room and hallway, for example. This demarcation is almost always accompanied by walls and doors that define the limit of each activity and also of each floor – therefore, in each environment, the appropriate treatment is given to each type of floor installed.

In contemporary architecture, however, with the popularization of open plans and integrated spaces, it is increasingly common to sectorize spaces and organize flows based on smoother transitions such as furniture, small gaps, lowered ceilings, or even, changing floors. This change can be a simple change of material and paging, but it can also be the insertion of a decorative element, called "carpet", in a portion of the floor. For both situations, you need to think about how to combine different materials, textures and shapes.

The most common is to mark the transition between wet and dry area, as is the case with kitchens integrated with dining rooms. In this division, we often see the combination of warm floor, which can be wood, vinyl or laminate, with cold floor in the kitchen, which can be porcelain, ceramic or even hydraulic tile or granite.

Written by Giovana Martino

title: GENDER INEQUALITY IN ARCHITECTURE
description:
Imagine if there were no women in architecture industry, then we would have missed the astonishing works of architects like Zaha Hadid and Brinda Somaya and many more.

Design has long been a male-dominated field. Whereas times are gradually changing, a few firms have made a ponder exertion to create their workplaces more efficient and equal by advancing sex uniformity. Firms that have made a commitment to building an inclusive, representative team are able to reap the benefits of all that women have to offer the profession.

Surveys shows that while women account for nearly half of graduates from architecture programs, they only make up about 15 percent of licensed architects. Considering that women make up more than 50 percent of the population, it’s important to ask ourselves how we can make changes to this statistic.

Need of guides : In common, architecture firms need relatable female guides who can offer assistance youthful ladies entering the field create professionally. The “mini me” impact can moreover play out, as individuals (regularly unwittingly) float towards mentoring those who see the same as they do or distinguish with their interface. As a result, directors, who are most frequently male, tend to select male staff to coach, create, and prepare for advancement.

Wage Inequality: Especially for those at the starting of their career, the design industry is known to be less monetarily profitable than other businesses. In expansion, the wage gap between males and females within the design industry influences women’s discernment of how companies esteem them. Many women feel underestimated within the male-dominated architecture industry, so they look for money related rewards in other showcase divisions where the wage gap between guys and females is lower or non-existent.

Recognition of Female Pioneers: Within the design world, as in other callings, solid female administration is now and then seen contrarily. Ladies pioneers may be looked down on as “bossy” or “shrill” instead of conclusive or visionary.

While some of these issues, such as the lack of financial incentive, are specific to the field of architecture, the majority apply to most professions. And, as with most professions, there are real benefits to remedying the lack of women in architecture.

Sreeraj Jagan.

title: 5 BEST PERGOLA DESIGNS WITH ROOF TO CREATE A STUNNING GARDEN FEATURE
description:
Everyone recognises a pergola; they are typically made of wood but can also be made of sturdy stones, with four columns supporting a slatted top. They add shade, structural definition, and a sense of privacy to any outdoor space, making them ideal for seating areas. Such areas can be easily transformed into a garden bar or kitchen. However, when it comes to pergola designs with roof, there are numerous options that are available. 

Yet, before learning more about these pergola designs ideas, it is essential to know what exactly they are. Start from the basics as we take you on a delightful journey in this blog.


What Is A Pergola?

A pergola is a wide-open, wall-less structure with four support beams and a fancy roof design, such as a lattice. Unlike other backyard accents, Pergolas do not typically have a protective roof because its primary purpose is not to shield the users. 

You can install screens on the walls and roof of your pergola to provide shade and protection against natural elements. People are often searching for pergola designs with roof to find the best way to cover the open area of their pergola during harsh weather conditions. 


Pergola Designs With Roof


Stone Pergola

A stone pergola is a classic choice that looks fantastic with complementing outdoor decor. However, if your space is prone to temperamental weather, a bit more shelter overhead may be in order.

Consider purchasing some climbing plants to create a canopy of fragrant blossoms around your stone pergola and on the pergola designs with roof. Roses, jasmine, and honeysuckle are ideal for a romantic, cottage-garden look and will add a touch of romance to any outdoor seating area or pathway. You can also make a stone pergola look more spacious by using natural stone paving beneath it.


Fabric Covering

Most homeowners choose water-resistant materials to add a layer of protection to the space below from the sun and rain. Such pergolas are made out of long-lasting fabric stretched across the rafters. You can choose to install a simple fabric or a printed material to suit the aesthetic appeal of your place.

The biggest problem with this pergola designs with roof is that water, dirt, and debris can cause mould or mildew to grow on the cloth. This is often impossible to remove, necessitating the installation of new panels.


Retractable Canopies

Retractable roofing is a practical and modern pergola designs alternative since it gives you the full pergola experience while also allowing you to retract the roof as if it never existed.


It begins as a full-roof pergola, shielding greater regions from the elements. This option is also available in motorised variants, which means you will not have to perform any manual effort every time you want to relax in your pergola. Such a setting is extremely useful if you are looking to shelter a hot tub or comfy sofa from the weather. 


Steel Pergola

People living in cities with harsh weather conditions can also opt for steel pergolas. Such pergolas last longer compared to other materials but are not so popular due to their appearance. You can get the steel structure painted or covered in some other material to make it more attractive. But many of such options are not sustainable and hence not recommended.


Bamboo

You can design and install an overhead framework made of bamboo canes to give your pergola a rustic look. If you install the pergola on a pathway, these canes could be fixed over trees instead of stone pillars. Over the years, the branches from these trees will crawl on the bamboo net and make a green shade over the pathway.


Such features could give your garden or backyard a distinctly natural feel. You can create a unique pergola designs attached to house using bamboo and other natural material.


Pergola Designs With Roof: What Should You Choose?

There is an elegance to pergola designs with roof. More importantly, they provide function and durability, the latter of which heavily relies on the material of the roof.

Choose what is best for you based on the weather conditions in your area. Stone, for example, is one of the best materials suited for pergola roof designs. It fits almost every kind of design. These can be useful because they can be easily illuminated with recessed spotlights and support other design ideas. A Pergola coupled with natural stone flooring can also provide aesthetic appeal to your outdoor space.


Conclusion

Design is about more than simply creativity; it's also about common sense. Consider how often you will be using your pergola and at what times of the year when choosing a roof. The best option for your home is determined by your particular design aesthetics and what you require for maximum functionality. However, if you choose to install a stone pergola at your home, consider World of Stones to get the best quality and roof pergola designs.
